Address: 635 Portland Hills Drive Dartmouth, Nova Scotia
about: The friendliest little neighbourhood pub in the whole wide world.
public transit: We are located directly next to the Portland Hills Bus Stop!
products: The best food and beverages you ever did have!
column44: We, Michael and Pamela Casey, took over Finbar’s Irish Pub in Bedford in October of 2004. The business had some challenges, to say the least, but we saw a lot o...f potential and we knew with a little luck, a few good people, and a lot of hard work we could really do something special.  We wanted to create a place that was friendly and inviting, a neighbourhood pub that offers fantastic food, great service and a feeling of familiarity and comfort for everyone. The community of Bedford and the surrounding area has been incredibly supportive and we’d like to take this opportunity to thank our loyal patrons for helping us so much over the years.  In June 2013 we opened our second Finbar’s in Portland Hills, Dartmouth, and we couldn’t be happier with the results! We’ve tried to bring the same sense of community that our patrons have come to expect in Bedford and the response has been terrific. We’re meeting new friends every day and having a great time in general.  Finbar’s is our baby, we live it every day and we love it. We even got engaged kneeling on the bar in front of all our friends and patrons.  We wouldn’t be in this business if we didn’t enjoy people so please introduce yourself on your next visit, we’d love to meet you. about: Folkus is a roots-based music series held in the colder months in beautiful Almonte, Ontario. We offer 4 shows per season held at Almonte Old Town Hall.
general information: Our Venue  All of our concerts are held in the Old Town Hall in Almonte, Ontario. Built in 1884, the auditorium’s soaring ceiling of hand-hewn Douglas Fir beams... offers an acoustic setting unparalleled in the area. Our space has been used for recording classical and pop concerts for CBC Radio 2, folk albums by local artists, and even rock albums by visiting artists.  Our Town Almonte is about 30 minutes west of Ottawa, and well worth the drive. Come early and shop in our intimate downtown, grab a bite at one of our fine dining establishments, or enjoy a beverage at our licensed bars. See More offers an acoustic setting unparalleled in the area. mission: Folkus has a mandate to promote local and Canadian roots artists. We are proud to have provided a warm room for performers in the cold months.

about: Organisme de bienfaisance à but non lucratif qui a pour but de recueillir des fonds afin de soutenir le CISSSAT dans l’amélioration de la qualité des soins et des services de santé offerts à Rouyn-Noranda.
mission: Recueillir des fonds afin de soutenir le CISSS de l'Abitibi-Témiscamingue dans le maintien et l’amélioration des soins et services offerts à la population.
company overview: POUR QU'IL CONTINUE DE BATTRE... Campagne de financement 2018-2019 de la Fondation hospitalière de Rouyn-Noranda.  L'OBJECTIF : Acquérir des équipements spécialisés en électrophysiologie. Pour que votre cœur continue de battre en santé!
column44: MISSION Recueillir des fonds afin de soutenir le CSSS de Rouyn-Noranda dans le maintien et l’amélioration des soins et services offerts à la population.  ... VISION Mériter le privilège de demeurer le choix des donateurs telle est la vision de la Fondation.  VALEURS La reconnaissance, la transparence et l'innovation constituent les éléments qui, avec la mission, guident continuellement les administrateurs et la direction dans leur prise de décisions.  HISTORIQUE La Fondation hospitalière du CSSS de R-N est un organisme de bienfaisance à but non lucratif qui a vu le jour en février 1985 grâce au soutien financier de la corporation Les Amis des malades.  Dès lors, le nouvel organisme met en place un conseil d'administration, composé de membres influents issus de différents milieux, susceptibles d'aider la Fondation à amasser des fonds auprès de la population et des entreprises. Depuis, quelque quinze personnes s'affairent à administrer bénévolement les dons recueillis dans le cadre d'une gamme variée d'activités et de programmes. about: All of our social media links & event listings can be found on http://www.fortunesoundclub.com/
public transit: yes, bus stop right in front
mission: You Can't Test The Sound!
company overview: instagram.com/fortunesound twitter.com/fortunesound  facebook.com/fortunesound... youtube.com/user/FortuneSound     From deep within the loins of Chinatown comes the rebirth of Vancouver's nightlife in the form of Fortune Sound Club. What was once the infamous Ming’s Chinese restaurant, the revamped space focuses on innovative design, art that can’t be messed with, and eco-friendly features, all of which are highlighted by the most official sound system. Nuanced by the grit and grime of the historic locale, Fortune Sound Club seamlessly blends high and low; downtown, up-from-the-street ambience in a clean and modern setting.  The intimate and innovative space by Orangutang Design is equal parts quality, function, conscientiousness, and aesthetic appeal. Eco-friendly design specs include recycled gluellam beam bar tops, table tops, and shelving; locally-manufactured LED lighting, a new HVAC system, T5 fluorescent lighting, low VOC paints, TOTO <http://www.totousa.com/> low-flow toilets and urinals, as well as a locally-designed and built stainless steel custom bar.  Artistic collaborators include street artist Shepard Fairey and streetwear designers Rick Klotz of freshjive and Kenta Goto of brknhome. Shepard Fairey’s massive install greets you at the front door and follows you up into the main space, while two custom ‘Designed By’ artist series rooms from Rick Klotz (for Timebomb <http://www.timebomb.bc.ca>) and Kenta Goto (for Livestock <http://www.deadstock.ca>) will be open for you to just chill in and/or available for private parties upon request.  The world-renowned Funktion-One Soundsystem <http://www.funktion-one.com> stands magnificently among the venue’s exposed beams and gilded brick walls. Fortune Sound Club has been designed around the sound system with minimal hard surfaces in order to maximize the technology. The choice of Funktion-One speaks to Fortune Sound Club’s very essence - to respect the sense of sound and how it is integral to the Fortune experience at an organic level. This exceptionally high calibre of sound quality creates a new paradigm for nightlife by providing an incredible platform to connect with the crowd. Funktion-One sound combined with an eclectic mix of music and performances is what makes it one bad mutha that will surely honour all of your indiscretions.  To complement the Funktion-One Soundsystem, Fortune Sound Club offers a custom DJ booth, which can cater to a four-turntable battle or any house aficionado. In the main space, a 16-foot-by-16-foot stage opens up to a reclaimed, red oak dance floor with plenty of bounce for the knees. Fortune Sound Club presents the freshest goods, whether it’s for a one off party, a special event, a live show, or one of our weekly jams.  Through the progressive and modern interior design, superior sound system, and overall commitment to love of music, Fortune Sound Club adds a new dimension to Vancouver nightlife. It offers a much needed breath of air – fresh in next level ways, thick with smoke machine haze, permeated by dance floor lights, and vibrating with the maddest sound that no one can test. See More youtube.com/user/FortuneSound     From deep within the loins of Chinatown comes the rebirth of Vancouver's nightlife in the form of Fortune Sound Club. What was once the infamous Ming’s Chinese restaurant, the revamped space focuses on innovative design, art that can’t be messed with, and eco-friendly features, all of which are highlighted by the most official sound system. SATURDAYS Once upon a time, the great Marvin Gaye asked "What's Going On?" Today, we want to know "Sup Fu?" Fortune Sound Club is pleased to present a night with a nod to the legendary house parties of yore that is firmly rooted in the good-times production of the present. Fun and free of pretension, Sup Fu? Saturdays features two rooms, DJs both iconic and on the come-up, and a mix of everything under the table to make you move and smile. Sup Fu? column44: For over 30 years, the Free Times Cafe has been a staple on the Toronto roots music scene, with nightly live music showcasing some the best folk and acoustic ar...tists in the city.  In addition a diverse menu of Jewish, Middle Eastern, and Canadian dishes, we also serve up daily market-fresh specials, and are famous for the traditional Jewish fish and dairy buffet on Sundays.  Food delivery by Foodora, UberEats, and Just Eat. See Moretists in the city. company overview: Le Festival St-Ambroise FRINGE de Montréal est une célébration internationale des arts multidisciplinaires qui encourage la créativité sans limites tels le théâ...tre, la comédie, la musique, la danse, la poésie et plus, provenant de plus de 500 artistes.   The St-Ambroise Montreal FRINGE Festival is an international multidisciplinary arts festival celebrating creativity without limits that includes theatre, music, comedy, dance, spoken word and more from over 500 performers. Full Circle presents the annual Talking Stick Festival. The organization also presents ongoing Aboriginal  events and workshops. www.fullcircle.ca
mission: Full Circle speaks of many images...  * full gathering of people - all races, cultures,   communities, perspectives... * completeness, inclusiveness, wholeness * the completion of a journey * unceasing movement - no beginning or ending.   Margo Kane established Full Circle First Nations Performance in 1992, with principles in mind that reflect these images. Full Circle creates opportunities for Aboriginal artists, writers and performers to express the reality of First Nations experiences and to work in harmony with First Nations traditions while engaging contemporary, interdisciplinary theatrical techniques. Full Circle provides an environment that fosters the development of skills, ideas, exploration, and collaboration.  Full Circle also maintains a performance ensemble. The ensemble members are dancers, singers, actors, clowns, writers, and musicians. Margo Kane employs a collaborative approach through workshops that become research and training projects for all participants. Full Circle's skilled and talented artists are excellent creative ambassadors for Aboriginal communities and valuable role models for emerging Native artists. A number of them have moved on to practice as actors, performing artists, musicians, visual artists, and writers in mainstream theatre in Canada. See More * completeness, inclusiveness, wholeness * the completion of a journey * unceasing movement - no beginning or ending. column44: Come get a little taste of Prince Edward Island at Gahan House Halifax! The Gahan House name has always meant high quality food, great beer, and an unforgettabl...e experience. The Murphy Groups foray into beautiful Halifax, Nova Scotia in 2014 has added even more to the Gahan experience, with an oyster bar that serves world famous Malpeque Oysters.  Malpeque Oysters are known for their fresh taste and decadent flavor, and originate in our first home of Prince Edward Island. They go great with a fresh handcrafted Gahan Ale, which is brewed just a few hours away at our P.E.I brewery. Come say hi and enjoy the Gahan experience! See Moree experience. about: **PAGE OFFICIELLE** Gambrinus, bière artisanale & Bouffe sympa
column44: Le Gambrinus c'est aussi...  Lundi BOCK "É" BIÈRE: Tous les pichets en spécial à 7,75$... Mardi LIVE : Spectacle dès 21h00 Mercredi ON S'LIQUÉFIE: Staff night - Prix staff sur la bière pour tout le monde !!  Pinte à 5,50$ et pichet à 7,50$ Jeudi et Vendredi SCEAU EN FOLIE: Chaudière d'ailes de poulet à partager à 25$ dès 21 h Samedi MOULES DU JOUR ET FRITES à volonté à 18,92$ + taxes    Que signifie Gambrinus ? "Faute de dieu, la bière s'est donnée un roi en GAMBRINUS, personnage mythique chevauchant son tonneau de bière, une chope à la main. Il apparaît au XVIe siècle, notamment à Nuremberg, dans un poème de Burkart Waldis, daté de 1543. GAMBRINUS ne dispose pas d'un support historique sérieux, mais on l'a déjà identifié à Jean 1er, duc de Brabant, appelé aussi Jean Primus. Au XIIIe siècle, il célébra une victoire militaire par un immense banquet où la bière était reine." about: Located right at the four corners of downtown Brampton, Garden Square is the spot for FREE live entertainment all summer long.   Account is monitored between 9am-5pm
column44: Brampton’s downtown is unique and a vibrant destination in the heart of the city with Garden Square being the venue of many colourful programs and events. The G...arden Square at the four corners is Brampton’s home to FREE entertainment all year long.  The square offers a variety of weekly artistic, cultural and theatrical events which provide amusement for all ages.  An exciting project is underway in Downtown Brampton! Construction has begun on a large LED screen that will be positioned on a pavilion structure near the corner of Main and Queen Streets. The screen will greatly expand the range of opportunities for entertainment, special events and live performances in the square, and increase its appeal as an everyday gathering place. Learn more about this and other Downtown Beautification Initiatives. See Morearden Square at the four corners is Brampton’s home to FREE entertainment all year long. about: The Gibsons RC Legion #109 is a non-profit org. It helps service veterans, provides community services and offers  entertainment/meals to members/guests.
column44: The Royal Canadian Legion Gibsons Branch #109 is the local branch of a volunteer-run, non-profit national organization committed to making a difference in the l...ives of Veterans and their families, providing essential services in our communities, and remembering the men and women who sacrificed for our country.  Founded in 1925. Membership includes people who have served as military, Royal Canadian Mounted Police, provincial and municipal police, Royal Canadian Air, Army and Sea Cadets, direct relatives of members and also affiliated members. Membership is now also open to the general public. The Gibsons Legion Branch #109 brings special luncheons, Tuesday Lunch days, Friday Night Dinners, Saturday live entertainment, pool/billiards, darts, hall rentals, bingo nights, meat draws and much, much more for our community. about: The world's oldest LGBTQ Bookstore, established in 1970 in Toronto.
public transit: Via TTC, Wellesley Subway Station. We are located on the West side of Yonge St., just North of Wellesley St.
column44: Glad Day Bookshop is the first Canadian and the longest surviving lesbian and gay bookstore worldwide. Serving the queer community since 1970, we specialize in ...offering the widest possible selection of lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans literature, both in and out of print, as well as DVD, magazines and novelties. Glad Day also NOW A COFFEE SHOP & BAR serving fair trade, local, handcrafted and delicious drinks. We have also partnered with CARDINAL RULE and they are running our kitchen every day 11am-10pm, except for Mondays. column44: Awarded Amherstburg's 2018 New Business of the Year, GL Heritage Brewing Company is a brand new brewhouse, tasting room, beer patio and retail shop.  Now open t...emp hours during covid-19:  walkin/curbside pickup Fri 2-7, Sat/Sun 12-5.  Delivery available Wednesdays.  Surrounded by a field of newly-seeded barley destined for your glass, GL Heritage joins the booming brewery scene in Windsor Essex to add another great stop where you can expect high quality, award-winning, hand-crafted beer and good people. Act Name: Goderich Celtic Roots Festival and College
about: The ultimate Celtic experience on the shores of Lake Huron. 10 days of musical madness including week-long workshops for children and adults, a three-day traditional music festival, and a rural outreach concert series.
mission: The aim of the Goderich Celtic Roots Festival and Celtic College is to foster the preservation and continuation of traditional Celtic art forms through exposure..., participation and education. Forming new generations of artists and participants is absolutely essential to the survival of these living traditions. The Festival, College and Celtic Kids Day Camp, therefore, create and support year-long educational and participatory programmes, as well as instrument loans to help bring forward the new generations that will live and participate in our valued traditions. If you share our goals, you can participate by helping us to fund the charitable organization we have created to finance these programs.  All contributions are tax deductible. Act Name: Gordon Pinsent Centre for the Arts
Address: 3 Cromer Avenue Grand Falls, Newfoundland and Labrador
about: The Gordon Pinsent Centre for the Arts was opened officially as the Grand Falls Arts and Culture Centre in 1971. With the amalgamation of Grand Falls and Windsor, it became the Grand Falls-Windsor Arts and Culture Centre .
general information: Watch for our postings of upcoming events.
column44: The History of the Gordon Pinsent Centre for the Arts: The Gordon Pinsent Centre for the Arts was officially opened as the Grand Falls Arts and Culture Centre ...in July of 1971. With the amalgamation of Grand Falls and Windsor, it became the Grand Falls-Windsor Arts and Culture Centre. As of July 12, 2005, it became the Gordon Pinsent Centre for the Arts, in honour one of Grand Falls native sons - actor and writer Gordon Pinsent, on the occasion of his 75th birthday, and during the town's Centenary. The story of how this building came to be re-constructed in Central Newfoundland is a very interesting one. The building began it life in Montreal as part of Expo 67, “Man and His World”. It was the Czechoslovakian Pavilion which housed many of that country’s cultural treasures and technological innovations. Popular Lore : On Tuesday, Sept.5, 1967 at Gander International Airport, a Czechoslovakian Airliner crashed on take off. Of the 69 people on board, 32 died instantly and five died later in hospital. Without the rescue efforts and dedication of the people from the James Paton Memorial Hospital in Gander, the Central Newfoundland Hospital in Grand Falls, and local rescue workers, more lives would have been lost. In 1968, as a gesture of gratitude, the Czechoslovakian Government transported to this site the major complex from its pavilion at Expo '67 in Montreal. It was reconstructed by the Newfoundland government and kept the exact same design and layout as the original structure. It took several years to complete the reconstruction due to financial problems, but finally the Centre was officially opened in July of 1971. The facts: The Czechoslovakian Pavilion at Expo 67 was designed as a temporary structure which could be easily disassemble and reassemble. It was hoped that this feature would help in the sale of the building. The Newfoundland Government of the day had expressed an interest in buying the building but was not the first choice of the Czechoslovakian Government. After the aforementioned rescue efforts of the people of Central NL., the Province’s request to purchase may have been raised to the top of the list. The J. R. Smallwood government purchased the Pavilion for 230,000 crown with the intent of making it into and Arts and Culture Centre in Central NL. He also intended to name the Centre after the sixteenth century Roman Catholic Educationalist, Comenius, to honour the buildings Czech roots. The building was design by Czech Architects Miroslav Repa and Vladimir Pycha and the Centre still houses some of the artworks from the Pavilion when it was at Expo 67 in Montreal. The Pavilion was divided into two separate buildings. The restaurants and small theatre section of the Pavilion were re-assembled in Gander and the larger exhibition area was rebuilt in Grand Falls. In the Gordon Pinsent Centre for the Arts there is an art gallery, a four hundred seat theatre, and a public library. These features in the building are named for pioneers from the community of Grand Falls. The theatre is named the Neala Griffin Theatre, after the prominent theatre and performing arts enthusiast who lived in Grand Falls. She was president and director of the Northcliffe Drama Club and she was also involved with adult education in the region. The Art Gallery is named for Gwendolyn Cooper. She was the wife of the mill manager in the early days of the town and also a prominent arts supporter. Mrs. Cooper arranged many arts exhibits, taught art, and encouraged many young artists to pursue their artistic dream. She also started and encouraged the first performing arts group in this region. The Harmsworth Public Library, named in honour of the Harmsworth family which founded the Anglo-Newfoundland Co. Ltd., moved from its original location on Church Road to this building on November 30, 1971. This wonderful building continues to attract many cultural events. Performers and visual artists from all over the world have performed or exhibited in the Centre for the Arts. Throughout the year visitors and patrons alike are invited to view local, provincial, and national artworks and performers as well as use the public library as a resource centre. Housed in the Art Gallery are two permanent collections. The first is called "Project 2000", sponsored by the Central Newfoundland Visual Arts Society, which features fine examples of prominent Newfoundland born visual artists. The second collection, also sponsored by C.N.V.A.S., is called the “CNVAS Collection” and is comprised of works by visual artists who live in Newfoundland. The temporary gallery features works by local, regional, and provincial artists throughout the year. The following is an account of the airliner crash, as it appeared in a local newspaper at the time The Czech Plane Crash: Thirty two persons died instantly aboard a Czechoslovakian airliner which crashed at Gander on Tuesday, September 5, 1967. Two more died after being admitted to the Paton Memorial Hospital, at Gander. The third casualty, Mr.Pilato, who boarded the flight at Gander, passed away at Montreal General Hospital. The fourth, a man of Polish nationality, died at Halifax and another expired in Montreal General Hospital the following weekend. The Russian built IL 18 Turbo prop aircraft crashed seconds after taking off from Gander. The aircraft, in command of Captain Bacovsky, may have been attempting to land on the soft marsh when it hit the railway tracks and telegraph poles and somersaulted. The first survivors to be located were: a stewardess, flight engineer, radio operator, a man, his wife and four children. Seven hours after the crash, the last survivor, a woman with her legs badly injured, was located under a piece of wreckage. Sixteen of the bodies have not been identified except by nationality and sex. The remainder of the bodies were released by Magistrate Jack A. White of Gander and company planes belonging to Czechoslovakian Airlines and Cubana Airlines have since transported the bodies to Cuba and Prague. Authorities at the Victoria General Hospital, Halifax and the Montreal General have commended the Paton Memorial Hospital for the manner in which the survivors of the crash were prepared for transfer to their respective facilities. Of the original 37 survivors admitted to the hospital here, 20 were transferred to Halifax and 7 to Montreal. Two died at Paton Memorial and one of the seven transferred to Montreal, Mr. Pilato, has also died, bringing the death toll to 37 out of 69 persons on board the aircraft. The hospital in Gander was assisted during the emergency, by: The Central Newfoundland Hospital, Grand Falls; General Hospital, St. John's; St. Clare's, St. John's; Provincial Department of Health Nursing Service, St. John's; Victoria General Hospital, Halifax; Montreal General Hospital, Montreal; Red Cross Service, St. John's and Toronto; and the United States Naval Hospital, Argentia. Hospital Administrator Mr. Gover said, "The assistance received during the emergency was terrific." He made special mention of Les Gettel, Manager of Allied Aviation, for arranging transportation; members of the armed forces, both Canadian and American; members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police; Eastern Provincial Airways; blood donors; Department of Transport; and numerous others who came forward and offered their services. Though the hospital maintains a ten bed crash ward, it was not in use during the tragedy because there was ample room to accommodate the crash victims throughout the facility. The bodies of 29 victims left Gander on September 10th for the return trip to Prague. On hand for the simple ceremonies were: Rev. W. Vardy of the United Church; Rev. J.H. Moss of St. Martin's; Rev. J.P. McCarthy; the Hon. Charles R. Granger, representing the provincial government; Mr. James Tucker, M.P.; Magistrate Jack A. White of Gander; The Consul General of the Czechoslovakian Embassy in Montreal; Edward Bilek, president of the Czech airline; L. Kilack and airport manager, Jack James. Mr. Bilek said it was his feeling that the number of people who died would have been greatly increased had it not been for the prompt action of the staff at James Paton Memorial Hospital. He said people of Czechoslovakia would always be in debt to those who did so much. He said, "the interest and concern shown by the people of Gander, who came out for the ceremony, is also appreciated." Close to 1,000 people attended the ceremony. Final identification for all but two of the victims came from Prague late that afternoon. The Ilyushin IL 18D turbo prop airliner exploded into flames about 4000 feet beyond the end of Gander airport's runway. The aircraft, a Soviet built four propeller turbo prop aircraft, was owned and operated by CSA (Czechoslovakia State Airlines), and was only in service about three months and was practically new to CSA's fleet. It was given its certificate of airworthiness and registration on May 16, 1967. This aircraft was the mainstay of Soviet transport airliners in the early 1960's and was being built and exported to communist bloc countries. Hundreds were in service all over the world. The IL 18 was a modern passenger transport of sleek design and comparable to western standards of technology and was well proven in service with many airlines. The aircraft, an IL 18D registered OK WAI left Prague, Czechoslovakia for its final destination Havana, Cuba with two technical and refuelling stops at Shannon, Ireland and Gander, Newfoundland. The aircraft stopped at Shannon and continued its flight across the north Atlantic uneventfully to Gander. The crew which flew the plane to Gander deplaned and was replaced with a new crew stationed at Gander. The aircraft lifted off near the end of the runway appearing normal except for a shallow climb out. The air plane, with 8900ft. of runway behind it, pancaked into very boggy ground beyond the end of the runway. The right wing tip struck a radar mast and exploded. Many of the passengers thought it occurred in flight. However the explosion occurred when the left wing and propellers struck the Canadian National Railroad tracks. See Morein July of 1971. about: Discover a little piece of Ireland in the heart of Regina's Cathedral neighbourhood.
column44: While the Irish stouts, lagers and creamy ales at Shannon's Pub and Grill will make you feel like you’re on Dublin’s doorstep, the food will have you feeling li...ke you’re at a cozy inn on the Emerald Isle.  The Irish culture’s known for its warmth, character and hospitality, and Shannon’s delivers on all fronts. Drop in for the genuine Irish pub experience -- and a bit of ‘craic’ (Gaelic for fun)! about: By beer lovers for beer lovers
general information: Grimross is a locally owned Microbrewery with onsite growler sales and taproom.
column44: Grimross Brewing Co. seeks to craft wonderfully tasty Maritime beers. Although we don't intend to produce a single "style" of beer, owner and head brewer Stephe...n Dixon is inspired by the brewers of Belgium and Northern France.  Belgian brewers have produced a wide array of tastes and are renowned for their irreverent approach to brewing. Belgian brewers were some of the first to explore using different ingredients such as spices and fruit and explore different approaches to fermentation. In particular, Stephen is interested in the effect of different yeast strains. Most commercial brewers use one or more of the yeast strains of Saccharomyces. Grimross will explore the wild and wonderful array of organisms that can produce beer, including Saccharomyces, but also a "wild" yeast called Brettanomyces and the bacteria Lactobacillus and Pediococcus. By using these various organisms in different ratios and at different stages in fermentation, Grimross seeks to produce a variety of new beers, including sour and funky tastes and aromas. See Moren Dixon is inspired by the brewers of Belgium and Northern France.  Belgian brewers have produced a wide array of tastes and are renowned for their irreverent approach to brewing. Belgian brewers were some of the first to explore using different ingredients such as spices and fruit and explore different approaches to fermentation. In particular, Stephen is interested in the effect of different yeast strains. Most commercial brewers use one or more of the yeast strains of Saccharomyces. Grimross will explore the wild and wonderful array of organisms that can produce beer, including Saccharomyces, but also a "wild" yeast called Brettanomyces and the bacteria Lactobacillus and Pediococcus. By using these various organisms in different ratios and at different stages in fermentation, Grimross seeks to produce a variety of new beers, including sour and funky tastes and aromas.

about: Founded in 1992, the Guelph Youth Music Centre is a unique facility that educates, enriches and fosters the development of our youth through music and the arts.
column44: The idea of the Guelph Youth Music Centre (GYMC) began over 30 years ago when a group of community-minded individuals saw a need for a permanent facility in whi...ch Guelph youth could participate in music and arts activities. This initial group was made up of families and teachers from the Suzuki String School of Guelph which was looking for a new permanent home. After many years of fundraising, the SSSG saw the need for a larger, community vision. In 1985, the GYMC was formed and was given all funds raised by the SSSG.  In 1992, the former Heritage Seed Company, an historic post and beam building along the Speed river, was purchased by the City of Guelph and turned over to the GYMC under a long-term lease.  The centre opened in September 2001, following an extensive renovation that relied on more than 30,000 hours of labour and service from more than 100 volunteers.  The Centre was an immediate success, providing a forum for affordable leadership, teaching, rehearsal and performance for hundreds of local music and arts students. The Centre includes a beautiful 180-seat Recital Hall, a dance studio and 15 rehearsal and teaching studios. See Morech Guelph youth could participate in music and arts activities. about: RiversEdge Park & Amphitheater is located at 116 Dayton St in downtown Hamilton along the banks of the Great Miami River.
column44: Thing to know when attending concerts at RiversEDGE:  1) All concerts are free unless specifically stated otherwise.... 2) To be served alcohol at RiversEdge, you must be 21 or over and wearing a provided wristband. 3) Alcohol sold at RiversEDGE cannot leave the roped off area of the park. 4) No alcohol may be brought into the park under any circumstances. Alcohol is provided within RiversEDGE for sale at most concerts. 5) No coolers are allowed during events. 6) No pets are allowed during events. 7) No climbing on the sculptures. 8) No parking on grass under any circumstances. Parking is available at McDulin Garage (entrance at Third and Market Street) as well as on-street. 9) Have fun and please help us keep the park clean by using provided trash and recycling bins. about: Iain and Jeannie have been hosting House Concerts in our home for over 10 years.  We love to listen to live music and share it with friends and neighbours.
column44: We bring in musicians who we've heard and enjoyed at Folk Festivals or concerts.  We usually charge about $20 a person, and all proceeds go to the artists. about: The Best International Festival Experience on Canada's East Coast! September 10-15, 2019. www.harvestjazzandblues.com Twitter/Instagram: @Harvest_Blues
company overview: Atlantic Canada’s largest, most musically diverse festival! Fredericton comes alive for six days each September as hundreds of world class performers appear on ...dozens of stages, all conveniently located in Fredericton's beautiful and historic downtown. Whether you want to dance all night at a spicy Cajun party, listen to the raw sounds of electric blues, sway to some smooth jazz or just get your funk on, you’ll find something to tempt every musical taste – all at a price that’s easy on the wallet.  Known internationally for presenting the best in established and up-and-coming talent, great musical memories and a touch of the unexpected are what the Harvest Jazz and Blues Festival are famous for. about: In conjunction with BCLC, Hastings Racecourse & Casino will temporarily suspend all operations as of Sunday, March 15th at 11:59pm.
column44: Few sports offer as much excitement or international appeal as thoroughbred racing. That’s one reason Hastings Racecourse has been capturing the imagination of ...Vancouverites and visitors alike since 1889. Featuring live thoroughbred racing and simulcast racing from many of the world’s most prestigious tracks, Hastings is a legendary location with spectacular mountain and waterfront racing views.  We invite you and your family to come out to Hastings Racecourse. We’re open for live thoroughbred racing every weekend from April to November, Friday nights from June to September and year-round for simulcast racing. We offer a variety of dining experiences, from casual to fine dining. This year, 600,000 guests will wager over $150 million at Hastings as they enjoy over 40,000 live and simulcast races. Whether you’re visiting as a couple or as a group, our staff is committed to ensuring that your day at the track is a runaway success and a truly memorable experience. You can bet on it! On behalf of all of us at Hastings, we hope to see you at the track as we make this racing season another to remember. See MoreVancouverites and visitors alike since 1889. Page Types: Pub | Irish Pub | Live Music Venue
about: The Heart & Crown - Preston Street's Facebook home. Here you can find daily features, band listings, upcoming events, news and more.  Sláinte! #HnConP
column44: The most beautiful pub in the city with rich mahogany wood,  a circular copper bar and all imported tables and chairs  makes this pub truly inspired by Ireland....  The Heart & Crown Preston Street has the largest patio on Preston Street that wraps around the building, a great place for lunch or dinner or simply admire the hustle and bustle of Preston.   An obvious Italian stronghold in the area, it was originally the settlement of Irish immigrants. The Irish and Italian communities have a long-standing respect, and the melting pot demographics will enhance an already striking street.   The copper throughout the restaurant gives a glowing effect throughout the night and with live music from Thursday to Saturday evening; there is no better place to be. See More  The Heart & Crown Preston Street has the largest patio on Preston Street that wraps around the building, a great place for lunch or dinner or simply admire the hustle and bustle of Preston. Page Types: Jazz & Blues Club | Live Music Venue | Nonprofit Organization
about: Hermann's Jazz Club is the best place to visit for live jazz and blues in Victoria, BC. On June 15, 2020 the Arts On View Society, a nonprofit organization, negotiated a 5 year renewable lease to operate and continue this historic music venue.
column44: Hermann’s Jazz Club began 30 years ago at the Bastion Inn when Hermann Nieweler was persuaded by his friend Barry Stubbs to book Friday Harbor’s Island City Jaz...z Band for a weekend performance at his hotel. Hermann’s love of jazz had him establish the Dixieland Inn at the hotel.  Hermann moved the club to the current View Street location in 1986 when it was renamed “Hermann’s Jazz Club”.  Regulars at the club include the Tom Vickery Trio, CanUS Hot Jazz & Smooth Harmony and the Sunday late afternoon Dixieland Express.  Every Thursday night the Tom Vickery Trio play host to an energetic jazz jam, which attracts some fabulous musicians from the local area and occasionally visitors from elsewhere!   Hermann's Jazz Club is located at ground level and is fully accessible to wheelchairs. See Morez Band for a weekend performance at his hotel. Act Name: Black Lion Pub Homestyle Bakery Café
about: Homestyle Bakery/Black Lion Pub offers great food, great entertainment and a vast amount of beers on tap in the beautiful Beaurepaire Village, Beaconsfield
column44: HISTORY: The Bakery & Cafe have been in business since 1994. Evolving from a bakery & cafe whose first seat was a bench seat out of a mini van in a charming but... tired old house....to a multi-level restaurant with 2 terraces & 2500 square foot bakery in a brand new building! Our first flour purchase was a 10 pound bag and it took forever to use it. Now we use 100 plus pounds per day.  THE BAKERY/CAFE: In the Bakery we make all kinds of things: from simple white loaves to hot pepper bread, bagels and anything in between! We make cookies, pies & cake ( our carrot cake is our trademark and is to DIE FOR!) just to name a few sweets and we're always adding more to the mix. The baking is done every morning and all of our non-speciality breads are made with no fat added. These non-fat loaves include Whole Wheat, Potato & Oat, Flax (ground just right to absorb the omega 3), Cracked Wheat, Multigrain, Marble & Pumpernickle. All of our breads & baked goods are served on our Menus (sandwiches, burgers, homemade croutons...) or simply for you to takeout.  THE PUB: If you want to see a beautiful bar with high ceilings, a beautiful terrace overlooking Beaurepaire Village, a great atmosphere and friendly waitstaff then the Blacklion Pub is for you! It's a great place for lunch or dinner, just by yourself or with a group of people. We also do big groups, parties and meeting space for whatever your occasion may be.  We've got great food, especially our burgers, fish & chips, steaks and nightly specials....We've got over 12 beers on tap and 7 bigscreen TVs for the Habs Games of course! This is the place to be at any time of day! {Please keep in mind that we are a licensed restaurant and a minimum food purchase is required with alcohol service} See More tired old house....to a multi-level restaurant with 2 terraces & 2500 square foot bakery in a brand new building! Our first flour purchase was a 10 pound bag and it took forever to use it. Now we use 100 plus pounds per day.  THE BAKERY/CAFE: In the Bakery we make all kinds of things: from simple white loaves to hot pepper bread, bagels and anything in between! We make cookies, pies & cake ( our carrot cake is our trademark and is to DIE FOR!) just to name a few sweets and we're always adding more to the mix. The baking is done every morning and all of our non-speciality breads are made with no fat added. These non-fat loaves include Whole Wheat, Potato & Oat, Flax (ground just right to absorb the omega 3), Cracked Wheat, Multigrain, Marble & Pumpernickle. All of our breads & baked goods are served on our Menus (sandwiches, burgers, homemade croutons...) or simply for you to takeout.  THE PUB: If you want to see a beautiful bar with high ceilings, a beautiful terrace overlooking Beaurepaire Village, a great atmosphere and friendly waitstaff then the Blacklion Pub is for you! It's a great place for lunch or dinner, just by yourself or with a group of people. We also do big groups, parties and meeting space for whatever your occasion may be.  We've got great food, especially our burgers, fish & chips, steaks and nightly specials....We've got over 12 beers on tap and 7 bigscreen TVs for the Habs Games of course! This is the place to be at any time of day! {Please keep in mind that we are a licensed restaurant and a minimum food purchase is required with alcohol service}

column44: Situated in the City Centre, The Horn is recognised as one of the top music pub venues in the UK. We won 'Entertainment Pub of the Year 2008' and 'Live Music Pu...b Venue 2008'.  We show around 80 acts a month and contrary to popular belief, 90% of these bands are original and not tributes.  There's a mass of history The Horn has to offer, including John Peel being a frequent customer back in the day. Numerous artists have kicked off their careers here, such as Kim Wilde (who was also a barmaid) and Paul Young. More recently bands such as The Gallows (held their album release party here), The Subways and Enter Shikari.  18+ (+14's must be accompanied by an adult)  We like local bands. If your interested in playing drop us a line at info@thehorn.co.uk See Moreb Venue 2008'. Page Types: Dance & Night Club | Performing Arts | Musician/Band
Address: Horse Meat Disco, Eagle London, 349 Kennington Lane London, United Kingdom
biography: Initially established in 2003 at The Eagle in London’s Vauxhall, Horse Meat Disco has evolved into a powerful force in queer and club culture as a whole, while ...staying local to its original home, each and every Sunday. Co-founded by James Hillard and Jim Stanton, and encompassing residents Severino and Luke Howard, the crew continue to maintain not only the weekly Sunday party, but a number of residencies in cities across the world, alongside a kaleidoscope of club appearances, festival dates and specially curated mixes.   Taking inspiration from a diverse, counter-cultural history of clubs and DJs, as well as from the sprawling, ever-expanding musical collections of it's resident crew, the sound of HMD is impossible to place. Nonetheless their style is undeniable, as is a popper-scented air of sheer authenticity. Rooted in hedonism, rhythm, freedom and emotion, a Horse Meat Disco set reinforces everything invigorating about disco, as comfortable as shattering old-school mirror ball cliches as basking in their light.   A typical HMD set blends classics, italo disco, house, oddities and punk funk, to conjure their initial spirit of “a queer party for everyone”, including, but not limited to, “Homos and Heteros, club kids, bears, fashionistas, naturists, guerilla drag queens and ladies who munch.” They have made appearances on every notable club scene in the modern world, as well as those beyond, and have long been a key fixture at festivals including Glastonbury, Bestival and Festival No.6.   Outside of the club, the Horse Meat Disco train rolls across the airwaves on Rinse FM, where the crew hold down a weekly residency every Sunday afternoon, serving as a pre and post-club Sunday lunch accompaniment, often delving into the more soulful shades of their sublime taste, often encompassing rave groove, gospel and whatever they can’t get away with on the dancefloor (which, as the years have proven, isn’t much). A series of expertly curated and acclaimed compilations for reissue label Strut helped further cement HMD’s formidable but communal reputation as disco masterminds, spreading their sound and many enviable obscurities into front rooms and record bags across the world. Their latest, ‘Meat Me Down the Disco’, was released on Z Records in 2017.  After decades of crate digging, globetrotting and partying, the HMD story continues apace. 2017 also saw the crew record their long-awaited contribution to BBC Radio 1’s ‘Essential Mix’, as well as their first joint foray into production, ‘Waiting For You To Call’, featuring Roy Inc., and released on their own, self-titled imprint. They are currently working on new music to be released with Glitterbox, with the new single ‘Let’s Go Dancing’ released in December 2018. column44: Horse Meat Disco began in a basement in London's Chinatown where co-founders James Hillard and Jim Stanton created a safe queer space for the disenfranchised di...sco citizens of London. Now at the end of 2016 and running in its fourteenth year Horse Meat Disco is dedicated to the industry of human happiness and it pumps it out every Sunday at their home EAGLE LONDON, http://www.eaglelondon.com.   Inspired by the halcyon days of New York nightlife including Mancuso’s Loft, The Paradise Garage, Nicky Siano’s Gallery and late lamented DJ Adam Goldstone. All four resident DJs Luke Howard, Severino, Jim Stanton and James Hillard have built a reputation for their fantastic parties and high quality disco sets. It’s the queer party for everyone; homos and heteros, club kids, bears, fashionistas, naturists, guerilla drag queens and ladies who munch. Musically it’s a glittering disco behemoth of classics, italo disco, house, oddities, Afro, punk funk in the friendliest venue south of the river.    Horse Meat Disco currently dj and run regular parties across the UK, Europe and the world over including a HMD Residency at Output in New York.    Horse Meat Disco has a weekly radio show with Luke and James at the helm on Rinse FM https://rinse.fm/artists/horsemeatdisco/.     All artist tour dates and booking information contact Ali  ali@backroom-entertainment.com or Oli oli@backroom-entertainment.com. See Moresco citizens of London. mission: The Hub City Music Festival is an event presented in partnership by the New Brunswick Cultural Center and Iguana Music and Sound.  The mission of the New Brunsw...ick Cultural Center is:  To stimulate the cultural development and economic growth of arts and entertainment in New Brunswick through the enhancement, preservation, maintenance and effective administration of existing and future venues that service the primary constituent base of the New Brunswick Cultural Center and by nurturing viable arts, educational and entertainment organizations that reach the diverse communities of New Brunswick and the region.  The purpose of Iguana Music is to strengthen communities by bringing people together through great music. We coordinate fully inclusive events in the New Jersey area and feature a wide variety of musicians, music and instrumentation. Most Iguana Music events have an additional fundraising emphasis for partnering non-profit charitable organizations, but all events serve to bring community members together in an open and inclusive way. about: Hughs Room Live, Toronto's beloved dinner and listening room is now a registered charity and non-profit community organization. To all our patrons, we want to say thank you for helping keep music live in our city. Join our community. Donate today.
products: Live Music, Food, Beverage, Hospitality, Art, Culture
awards: Best Blues Bar in Toronto 2018 Best Jazz Bar in Toronto 2018
column44: In January of 2017, Hugh's Room was forced to close its doors after sixteen (16) years of operation. The closure didn't last four (4) months before the communit...y rose up in support. Today, it is a thriving musical institution, operating as a registered charity and non-profit organization.  THE STORY Following the unexpected closure, there was an immediate and overwhelming response to the potential loss to the musical community, with substantial coverage in the local and national media (Toronto Star, Globe & Mail, Toronto Sun, Now, Exclaim, National Post, Jazz-FM, CBC, CTV, Global, insidetoronto.com, WholeNote, and many others).    Many members of the music community and public asked how they could help to save or revive their beloved Hugh's Room.  In response, a working group of volunteers assembled developed a viable plan for re-opening Hugh's Room as a not-for-profit organization. The group included lawyers, business people, accountants, music promoters, publicists, venue operators and members of the community (members are listed below).  Grit Laskin was named spokesperson for the working group.    The group has determined that Hugh's Room can clearly sustain itself financially going forward.  With the right infrastructure and community support, the legacy of Hugh's Room can be continued.  Toronto can continue to have a destination venue that presents the genres, variety and high quality of music that Hugh's Room is renowned for worldwide.  THE TEAM The working group came together informally, in response to the news of Hugh’s Room’s closing.  All are fans of Hugh’s Room, and wanted to explore how it could re‑open as a community‑owned venture. It includes:  Jeremy Darby, owner Canterbury Music Co (recording studio)  Howard Gladstone, businessman, musician, co-founder Toronto City Roots Festival 2004-2010  Jane Harbury, freelance publicist, has worked for Hugh's Room for many years  Brian Iler, lawyer, chair Northwinds Folk Festival (1984/85), engaged with many community initiatives  Grit Laskin, musician, luthier, member Order of Canada, spokesperson for the Hugh's Room working committee  Judith Laskin, retired educator, founding board member CFMA,  director The Woods Music & Dance Camp, past board member Mariposa Folk Festival under Estelle Klein  Brian Litvin, accountant and musician  Frank Saunders, businessman, involved with presentation and production of folk events  Rob Young, advertising executive and musician See Morey rose up in support. Today, it is a thriving musical institution, operating as a registered charity and non-profit organization. company overview: ICI par les arts est un organisme à but non lucratif incontournable qui se spécialise en développement par le biais des arts. Depuis 1998, nous promouvons et re...ndons accessible les arts comme outils dynamiques et durables de développement social, économique et culturel.  Nos interventions, ateliers et événements sont créés sur mesure, selon les besoins et problématiques exprimés. Que ce soit auprès des petits, des adolescents ou des aînés, nous nous adaptons afin d’accueillir chaque individu là où il en est, pour ainsi l’encourager et l’accompagner à aller là où il voudra.  Convaincu du rôle que jouent les arts dans le développement personnel des individus et dans la vie communautaire, nous sommes devenus un chef de file en la matière, voire même un outil de référence. L’innovation et l’émergence de nouveaux talents font également partie de notre quotidien. column44: Leader parmi les institutions muséales, actif et reconnu dans Lanaudière, l’Île-des-Moulins se déploie aux abords de la rivière des Mille-Îles sur le lieu d’ori...gine d’une magnifique seigneurie. Ses cinq majestueux bâtiments témoignent encore aujourd’hui de la vitalité d’autrefois. De 1976 à 1993, ces bâtiments ont été restaurés : le Bureau seigneurial (1976), le Moulin neuf (1978), le Moulin à scie et le Moulin à farine (1983-1984) de même que la Boulangerie (1993). Le site est aujourd’hui géré par la Société de développement culturel de Terrebonne (SODECT) qui voit aussi à la gestion de La Maison Bélisle. Ce site enchanteur est un lieu de destination couru et accueille plusieurs dizaines d’événements annuellement. Il est classée ensemble de bâtiments patrimoniaux par le Ministère des Affaires culturelles depuis 1973. See Moregine d’une magnifique seigneurie. about: I Musici de Montréal met son talent, sa polyvalence et sa créativité au service de la communauté dans une perspective de stimuler l’interprétation, le rayonnement et le développement des musiques de concert.
biography: Fondé en 1983 par Yuli Turovsky, l’Orchestre de chambre I Musici de Montréal est composé de 15 musiciens d’exception, dont le répertoire varié s’étend du 17e si...ècle à aujourd’hui. Jean-Marie Zeitouni, chef d’orchestre et artiste visionnaire, en est le directeur artistique depuis 2011. I Musici de Montréal interprète et fait la promotion d’une programmation originale misant sur la découverte, la tradition et l’innovation en musique classique. Depuis ses débuts, l’Orchestre accorde une place toute particulière aux artistes canadiens émergents et s’associe à des artistes de renom, du Canada et de l’étranger, en plus d‘agir comme catalyseur créatif dans la ville. I Musici de Montréal s’est produit devant des mélomanes d’une vingtaine de pays et jouit d’une discographie regroupant plus de 40 enregistrements. See Moreècle à aujourd’hui. company overview: The Indian River Festival offers a summer long series of concerts in a magnificent heritage church set within sight of beautiful Malpeque Bay. Discover excellen...ce in folk, jazz, blues, classical, choral, Maritime, world and contemporary music by the finest artists from Prince Edward Island and across Canada, all in the world class acoustical setting of Historic St. Mary’s, Indian River. products: A complete listing of dates for the 2019 season are available here: https://indianriverfestival.com/2019-summer-line-up/
awards: The Festival has received many accolades throughout the years including a Music PEI Award for Achievement in Classical Music, several ECMA nominations for event... and venue of the year, twice named in the Globe and Mail as one of the best small summer classical music festivals in Canada, and most recently, it was listed as one of the top summer classical music festival’s in Canada by CBC Music. See More and venue of the year, twice named in the Globe and Mail as one of the best small summer classical music festivals in Canada, and most recently, it was listed as one of the top summer classical music festival’s in Canada by CBC Music.
column44: In the 1970s and 80s, the St. Mary's Church, now home to the Indian River Festival, was in serious disrepair. At that time suggestions were made to tear down th...e Church as the parish alone could not afford to undertake the expensive renovations. Instead the "Save St. Mary's" campaign was launched in 1987. Due to an overwhelming response from area churches, businesses, individuals, families and other groups, the necessary renovations were paid for and completed within 3 years. One of the campaign initiatives was the "Sundays in the Summer" concert series which proved to be extremely popular and a successful source of revenue; however the volunteer core behind the series became stretched to the limit and in order to evolve to the next level into a separate entity and formal event, a dedicated focus was required.  Consequently, in 1996 the Indian River Festival Association Inc. was formed as an incorporated non-profit body for the presentation of fine music appropriate to the Church and to aid in the continuing upkeep and restoration of St. Mary's.  In fall of 2009 St. Mary's Church was decommissioned, a common fate for many rural churches in Prince Edward Island. After many months of negotiations, the Festival and the authorities of the Diocese of Charlottetown came to a final purchase agreement for St. Mary's Church. On December 15, 2009, Indian River Festival Association Inc. became the sole owner of this wonderful heritage building. While this news brings a lot of excitement, it also comes with the huge responsibility of preserving and maintaining St. Mary's for the benefit of future generations. What if that hot drink had a little liquor in it? What if that hot drink was served in a crazy elephant shaped tea pot and a mismatched china teacup? What if you got hungry & there was a hot pot of chilli on the stove ready to go and you could fill your belly without emptying your wallet? What if there was a place that was just there for everyone to enjoy and spend time and eve get inspired and put on a workshop or sell their crafts? Hula hoop class, Tarot reading, French lessons, spoken word, crochet, egyption pharoah head dressmaking class.... Infinitea - everything you can imagine. about: Friendship Through Culture - The JCCC is one of the largest and most vibrant Japanese cultural centres in the world. Follow us @JCCC_Toronto
general information: How to get here: Take the 100 bus from Eglinton Station (approx. 20 mins.), or the 100/100A/100D bus from Broadview Station (approx. 25 mins.).
column44: For over 50 years, the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre (JCCC) has served as the gathering point for the Japanese Canadian community and for those of non-Japan...ese ancestry who have an interest in things Japanese in the Greater Toronto Area.  Open to everyone regardless of race, religion, sex or age, the JCCC provides a place - and more importantly, the impetus - for the exchange of ideas; a showcase for those with Japanese artistic and athletic talents; social and intellectual events: the history and future of the unique Japanese-Canadian community.  The JCCC offers a wide variety of Japanese cultural programs and experiences for its 3,500 members - almost half of whom are of non-Japanese ancestry, and approximately 35 percent who are seniors. The JCCC showcases the creative energy and dedication of many talented artisans, musicians, dancers and martial arts practitioners.  The JCCC fosters mutual understanding and facilitates the exchange of information about Japanese culture with the community-at-large through a wide range of exciting programs. The Centre also works to build a spirit of co-operation and harmony among people of different cultures by coordinating community events and programs with other ethnic organizations.  Under the guidance of Kuwabara Payne McKenna Blumberg Architects, the JCCC has taken on a modern feel since moving from its original home at 123 Wynford Drive.  Registered charity # 118972967RR0001  Please direct any inquiries to jccc@jccc.on.ca, including information about classes and workshops, or visit http://www.jccc.on.ca/en/contact/ for a staff directory.  クラス・ワークショップを含むすべてのご質問はjccc@jccc.on.caまでお問い合わせください。または、こちら http://www.jccc.on.ca/en/contact/ よりスタッフディレクトリをご覧ください。 See Moreese ancestry who have an interest in things Japanese in the Greater Toronto Area. about: Jazz Bistro combines live jazz music and great food to offer a truly unforgettable experience in downtown Toronto.
column44: Located on Victoria Street just off Yonge-Dundas square, Jazz Bistro combines great music and great food to offer a truly unforgettable guest experience. Featur...ing live performances six nights a week, upscale casual cuisine inspired by fresh local ingredients and a wine selection to match, Jazz Bistro provides a unique social, cultural and culinary experience in a warm, contemporary environment.  Occupying the former Senator Steakhouse space, famous for being a top North American live jazz destination and having hosted world-class musicians. Jazz Bistro is re-inventing that legacy within a creative modernized design that respects guests and musicians alike. All three floors have been carefully curated to compliment and support live performance artists and provide a vibrant yet comfortable environment for guests. The main floor features a performance stage, complete with a state-of-the-art sound system and a one-of-a-kind Steinway piano nicknamed "Red Pops", along with a full bar and dining room. The second floor features a wine bar, dining that overlooks the performance stage as well as private dining facilities. The third floor features an event space with full bar and private semi-enclosed patio lounge.  Executive Chef Brad MacDonald, formerly of Centro and Sassafraz, has crafted a menu of bistro-style, seasonally inspired dishes using a blend of Mediterranean and Canada flavours. Locally grown, raised and sourced ingredients are the building blocks of a menu that inspire sharing amongst tables and jealously amongst neighbours. Brad's experiences, from growing up around his parent's rural Ontario diner to working on farms outside Stratford, Ontario to working under Alois Ming to his travels in Japan have all contributed to what will arrive at every table to whispers of adjacent curiosity.   A small yet elegant wine list compliments the flavours and aromas coming from the kitchen at Jazz Bistro, featuring accessibly priced private labels from both the New World (Canada, California, Washington, Australia, New Zealand, Argentina) and the Old World (Italy, France). 21st century versions of classic cocktails and local craft beer round out the beverage program that is sure to satisfy any sense or craving.   Jazz Bistro is the creation of respected Toronto socialites Colin and Joan Hunter. As lovers of music and fine dining, they've created a welcoming space to enjoy memorable nights of live music and great cuisine, filling a gap that was left in the Toronto entertainment scene after the closing of Top O' the Senator jazz club. Colin, a well-recorded crooner (and frequent performer at Jazz Bistro) understands that live jazz, great food and good wine are perfect compliments to each other. Joan, having a keen eye for detail, has left no stone unturned to ensure each guest feels the warmth of the space and the chill of the sound.   Enjoy a great meal, raise a glass in celebration and enjoy lingering sounds from a stage graced by some of the world's greatest jazz musicians. Your home for live jazz is closer than you think! Address: Heuther Hotel, 59 King Street North Waterloo, Ontario
about: The Jazz Room is a live music venue in Uptown Waterloo, Ontario. Shows every Friday and Saturday night, September - June. Operating in the Huether Hotel.
column44: It's a sizzling night club dedicated to the best in jazz music presentation.  Home to the Grand River Jazz Society (GRJS), the club has a dual mandate: to suppo...rt dedicated local musicians, and to bring exceptional talent from elsewhere for local audiences to hear.    The Jazz Room, located at the Huether Hotel in Uptown Waterloo, will be active from September to June, presenting music on Friday and Saturday nights on a continuous rotation of professional musicians. The stage will be dedicated to the best in local talent on Friday nights (8:30-11:30), while those coming from afar will take the same time Saturday headline.    In order to pay for the very high level of talent on our stage, a cover charge will be necessary upon entry (roughly the cost of a movie).  Grants and sponsorships will help lower the cover charge, and ensure proper compensation for musicians.    GRJS activities include fostering audience appreciation, education, outreach, etc.  The GRJS looks to foster partnerships with other jazz presenters such NUMUS, Neruda, local secondary and post-secondary institutions, The Uptown Waterloo Jazz Festival, and more.   Come out and experience the magic of great jazz in a prime spot for fun on the weekend! about: We are excited to announce that Keep the Beat Nelson will take place again this summer on Saturday, August 8th, 2020!  Keep the Beat is a student-run music festival fundraiser for War Child Canada. The event runs every summer in August.
general information: Keep the Beat Nelson is an annual music festival fundraiser for War Child Canada. War Child is an international non-profit humanitarian organization whose missi...on is to help children in war-affected communities reclaim their childhood through access to education, opportunity, and justice. War Child envisions a world where no child knows war, taking an active role in raising public awareness around the impact of war on communities and the shared responsibility to act.  Keep the Beat is student-run and held in Nelson's Lakeside Park each summer. All proceeds from Keep the Beat go directly to War Child Canada's many initiatives in countries including Uganda, Afghanistan, South Sudan, and Jordan, raising funds through personal donations, a silent auction, grants, and pledges. This year will be the 15th annual Keep the Beat festival, with over $150 000 raised since its inception. Along with raising money for a worthy cause, it also provides positive community growth and student volunteer opportunities, all while bringing the city together for a day of music, dancing and family fun! See Moreon is to help children in war-affected communities reclaim their childhood through access to education, opportunity, and justice. mission: Keep the Beat's mission is to raise funds and awareness for War Child Canada while providing positive community growth and student volunteer opportunities, and bringing the city together for a day of music, dancing and family fun!
company overview: War Child works to protect childhoods. Childhood is a pivotal time in our lives. But it is also fragile, and can be easily corrupted by the effects of war. By p...roviding access to education, opportunity and justice, War Child gives children in war-affected communities the chance to reclaim their childhood and break the cycle of poverty and violence.  War Child has worked in conflict areas since 1999. Over the years, our reach has grown substantially, benefiting hundreds of thousands of children and community members every year. The lessons learned over a decade and a half have helped us to develop and improve our work.  The children we dedicate our work to are the most marginalized and most vulnerable. Their lives have been torn apart by war. Their safety is compromised. Their families have lost all means of supporting them, and there is no longer education nor the legal protection that we take for granted. Many have been forced from their homes and, in many cases, their countries.  Local people are vital to our success. 95% of our staff are from the countries where we work. We have local partner organizations in each of those countries. They bring a wealth of knowledge and shared experience that ensures our work fits the needs of the community.  Childhood is shaped by many influences. Families, communities, schools, local authorities, and governments all have a duty of care for children and an influence on their lives. We work with them to ensure that children are given the support they need to overcome the effects of conflict.  Our work is only possible because of those who support us. This includes UN agencies like UNICEF and UNHCR, the European Union and the governments of Canada and the United States. This diversity is testament to our record of success. column44: Kenzington Burger Bar offers the finest fare for all burger lovers!   We are a growing burger bar restaurant with locations throughout all of Simcoe County. Since we opened our flagship location located in downtown Barrie, Kenzington Burger Bar has always been known for excellent and friendly customer service, and offers a welcoming and fun atmosphere. about: Come enjoy a classic English Pub experience, in one of the oldest operating bars in Winnipeg. Located in Winnipeg's historic Exchange District, it is the perfect pit stop to round out any day. See you soon.
column44: Located in the heart Winnipeg's historic Exchange District, the King's Head Pub has been a Winnipeg institution for three decades.  The King's Head Pub offers a... fantastic selection of food. From traditional pub fare, to authentic and delicious curry dishes that are made from unchanged family recipes. We also have one of the largest draft selections in the city, over 30 beers and lagers to be exact. Come try the best of Winnipeg's craft breweries, or satisfy that craving with an international favourite. The choice is yours.   In addition to crushing the food and beverage game, the King's Head Pub is also one of the premiere event locations in Winnipeg. Featuring a stage on the second floor with a full service bar, and a lower floor open for reservations that has been dubbed "The Duchess", the King's Head Pub can handle anything. Whether it's live music from different bands every weekend, live theatre acts during Fringe Festival, or weddings and socials featuring full service catering and entertainment, we got you covered.    For bookings and reservations please contact kingshead@kingshead.ca or call (204) 957-7710.   See you soon! See More fantastic selection of food. about: The Kingston Youth Shelter offers emergency shelter, transitional housing, and family mediation to homeless youth between the ages of 16-24.
general information: We provide a supportive, stable environment, and the tools and life skills to help youth emerge from their immediate or ongoing housing crisis. We believe that ...together we can reduce homelessness by giving youth the means to repair relationships at home or live independently during the transition to adulthood. See Moretogether we can reduce homelessness by giving youth the means to repair relationships at home or live independently during the transition to adulthood.
mission: The Kingston Youth Shelter strives to make a difference in the lives of homeless youth by offering a safe and supportive emergency shelter that encourages their growth and provides them with access to community resources.

general information: Terms of Use  This page is for sharing information on services, events and programs offered by the Corporation of the Town of Kingsville. ... Public comments posted to this page do not necessarily reflect the opinions of Councillors, managers or staff of the town.  The Corporation of the Town of Kingsville reserves the right to remove any content deemed inappropriate, and does not endorse any advertisements that may appear on the page.   Inappropriate content includes, but is not limited to:   * Sexual content or links to sexual content; * Content which may be deemed discriminatory in manner; * Profane, derogatory or defamatory language; * Any posts in violation of copyright and/or trademark law; * Any and all solicitations;  * Comments unrelated to the content posted by the Corporation of the Town of Kingsville; * Content that could be interpreted as election campaigning. column44: Nestled on the north shore of Lake Erie, Kingsville Ontario is Canada’s Southernmost Town. With an ideal growing climate, it's no surprise that fresh, locally g...rown fruits and vegetables fill the produce stands along our roads every season. Rich in history and Victorian era architecture, Kingsville strikes a compelling balance between valuing our heritage, and committing to growth and renewal.  Discover the natural beauty of our parks, sandy beaches and walking trails; visit our distinct wineries and restaurants, and experience a wonderful community spirit where culture and the arts thrive. Address: 979-985 Nepean Hwy Moorabbin Moorabbin, Victoria, Australia
about: Kingston Arts is dedicated to the development of arts and culture within the City of Kingston and the Greater Southern Region.   This page is monitored during business hours Monday to Friday 9am - 5pm.
column44: The City of Kingston boasts a vibrant arts and cultural scene, hosting a variety of arts spaces, arts and cultural organisations and services, professional and ...non-professional artists, creative industries and arts workers.  Kingston Arts aims to build on these strengths, increase the profile and support of creative industries within the community and foster more opportunities for creative engagement and cultural tourism.  Kingston Arts achieves this in a number of ways including through the delivery of a comprehensive and diverse calendar of performing, visual and community arts events and activities across three primary arts spaces: Kingston Arts Centre, Kingston City Hall and Shirley Burke Theatre.   Kingston Arts' performing arts programs are designed to showcase Melbourne's finest talent as well as acting as a platform for emerging artists.  For the visual arts, Kingston Arts' gallery spaces, including G1 and G2, G3 Artspace and The Bridge projection space, promote artistic excellence and innovation with diverse and thought provoking programs by both professional and emerging artists.   The City of Kingston also provides support through an annual Arts Grants program and the provision of affordable artist-in-residence spaces.    For the community, Kingston Arts programs events including the Lens Mist Photographic Award & Exhibition, a Maker's Market, Pop Up Bar and the City of Kingston's public art program.    Each of these initiatives enhance, strengthen and act on the community's desire to position Kingston as a liveable and creative city.  For further information phone our friendly Box Office team on (03) 9556 4440 or email arts@kingston.vic.gov.au     LOCATION  The City of Kingston is just 20 minutes drive from Melbourne's CBD, and Kingston Arts Centre and Kingston City Hall (formerly Moorabbin Town Hall) are only 100 metres from Moorabbin train station and buses. Les éditeurs ne publient pas les commentaires diffamatoires ou qui font usage d’un langage vulgaire ou abusif, pas plus que les commentaires incluant des attaques personnelles ou des allégations fausses ou non fondées. Les éditeurs se réservent en tout temps le droit de publier (en tout ou en partie) ou non les commentaires.  Avis concernant les médias sociaux : www.ccbn-nbc.gc.ca/fr/avis-important/#medias-sociaux

column44: Koerner Hall is one of the top concert venues in the world. This page is your source for information about concerts, special offers, artists, and more!  Coming ...from out of town? column44: In 1995, your hosts, Shelley Gallagher and Mark Jenkins built their home nestled in the woods along the shores of Lamb’s Pond.  With an engineering background a...nd interest in sustainable living, Mark designed the Timberframe home as an extension of the outdoors.  With over 25 years’ experience in Environmental Education, Shelley welcomes guests to explore and reconnect with their natural surroundings. We are interested in helping others to rediscover the healing powers of the natural environment.  Nature is integral to overall mind, body and spiritual wellness.  Many humans live without meaningful connections with the natural world.  FACILITIES Open concept Timberframe home with large kitchen and finished walk out basement. Large Ti Pi that can accommodate up to  25 people Boathouse with canoes, kayaks, row boat and sailboat. Bonfire pit near lake Hammocks and natural seating circles throughout property. Tranquil Zen garden with rock seating and water feature. Sugar Shanty Sauna and closed in Gazebo coming soon!  Facility Fee per day or per person. Please contact Shelley Gallagher to discuss how we can meet your needs in this unique setting. general information: The City of Langley has amassed a population nearly 27,000 people, developed a distinct cultural and social identity and asserted itself as “The Place To Be” fo...r economic activity in the Fraser Valley. The City of Langley has managed to retain its small city atmosphere and community spirit while offering all the amenities of a major urban centre, a unique trait which appeals to a wide spectrum of people and businesses. It continues to be a community where elected officials are visible neighbors and tax dollars are spent to address issues of local significance. See Morer economic activity in the Fraser Valley. Address: River Front Way Fredericton, New Brunswick
about: What are our house concerts all about?  Great music by professional artists in the small inmate setting of our home. See Notes for more information!
column44: See NOTES for detailed description.  To book a concert with us, please e-mail directly to: pmm@unb.ca.    To reserve seats for a concert, please e-mail directly... to: pmm@unb.ca.     We began in 2011 and have hosted over 140 concerts to date.  Our concerts are what we like to call "listening" events where the audience has a chance to hear every note and every word the artists produce.  In fact, we specifically ask guests not to talk during the performance except between songs.  In that sense, it differs from a house party in that the primary purpose is to listen to the concert.  It is a relaxed and casual atmosphere where we have lots of interaction between the artists and the audience.  There are two 45-minute sets with a 30-minute intermission.  We ask for a fee of $20 or $25 (depending the group size)  and all the money goes to the artists.  We usually have around 40 to 55 people.  People are encouraged to ask questions of the artists between songs - usually there is a lot of story telling leading up to each song. We are listed on www.acousticroof.ca and one way that artists contact us.  However, our preference is for artists too send us an e-mail to pmm@unb.ca.  Concerts usually start at 8 PM but everyone arrives around 7:30 PM and that gives us time to get everyone settled.  We provide chairs and glasses for drinks that people choose to bring or plates to serve snacks. Usually people bring something to drink and a snack to share at the intermission, but that is optional.     All seats must be reserved in advance by sending us an e-mail to pmm@unb.ca or by telephone to 457-0826.  Some concerts fill very quickly depending on how well known they are. about: The new last best frontier for beer @lastbestbrew
column44: It’s our privilege to be the community liaison for beer and beer culture and we don’t take this role lightly. The beers we make are a direct reflection of the v...alues and personalities of you –our customers and our community.   Our beers are fresh and delicious because we make them using the best ingredients for everything we produce. Which isn’t hard here in Alberta. We are literally surrounded by a sea of barley, making (in our opinion) Calgary the ‘Last Best’ opportunity for the craft brewing industry and brewers like us.    In fact, ‘Last Best’ goes all the way back to the turn of the 20th century when the Canadian government launched ‘The Last Best West’ campaign, calling Calgary the last best chance in the modern world for homesteaders to lay roots and shape their futures.    We think the accomplishments resulting from the first ‘Last Best’ initiative have paved the way for the budding craft beer and distilling industries here in Alberta.   We honour this historical spirit through our name and our unwavering commitment to making delicious well-crafted beer.  We’re the fourth location in the Bearhill Brewing Family of Breweries. Check out our other locations at bearhillbrewingco.ca See Morealues and personalities of you –our customers and our community. We honour this historical spirit through our name and our unwavering commitment to making delicious well-crafted beer.  We’re the fourth location in the Bearhill Brewing Family of Breweries. about: Bar de bières de microbrasserie et restauration.
column44: Il existe, aux limites de l'Ouest portneuvois, plus précisément à St-Casimir, un endroit où amateur et amatrices de bières trouveront refuge tout en partageant ...des moments sympathiques agrémentés de musique.  Depuis 2011, La Taverne offre un large éventail de produits provenant du Québec et de contrées plus lointaines. Avec ses 12 lignes de fûts, plusieurs importations privées et une majorité de bières de microbrasseries québécoises, cet établissement saura vous faire découvrir de nouveaux horizons. Aussi, La Taverne a su implanter son nom dans le domaine culturel en accueillant régulièrement des artistes en spectacles. See Moredes moments sympathiques agrémentés de musique.
