about: Situé à proximité de la rivière Jacques-Cartier et doté d'un cachet unique, le Moulin dispose d'une salle de spectacles, d'un bistro, d'une galerie d'art.
general information: Site web : www.moulinmarcoux.pont-rouge.org téléphone : (418) 873-2027
mission: La mission de la Corporation des lieux historiques de Pont-Rouge repose sur la mise en valeur du patrimoine et de la culture. Elle exerce un rôle de levier pour... le développement, la promotion et la diffusion de la culture. Cette mission s’assortit d’un engagement de rendre accessible à tous, des lieux vivants, habités par la culture et le patrimoine. See More le développement, la promotion et la diffusion de la culture. Cette mission s’assortit d’un engagement de rendre accessible à tous, des lieux vivants, habités par la culture et le patrimoine.
company overview: Fondée en 1973, sous le nom de Corporation du Vieux Moulin Marcoux, cet organisme s’est d’abord donné comme mandat de sauver de la destruction ce moulin et d’en... faire un lieu de culture pour tous. En 1997, elle devient La Corporation des lieux historiques de Pont-Rouge (C.L.H.P.R.) et élargit sa vocation à promouvoir la vie culturelle et à protéger les lieux historiques de Pont-Rouge. Cet organisme à but non lucratif possède présentement Le Moulin Marcoux et le site Déry acquis respectivement en 1973 et en 1979 de l’ancienne compagnie Domtar. La Fondation Déry-Marcoux lui est associée. Cette corporation est administrée par un conseil d’administration formé de bénévoles sur lequel siège aussi un représentant de la MRC de Portneuf, des représentants du service de la Culture et des Loisirs et du conseil de la Ville de Pont-Rouge. about: Canada’s number one convention & trade show facility, encompassing over 600,000 sq ft of flexible exhibit & meeting space in the heart of downtown Toronto.
public transit: http://www.mtccc.com/map.aspx
mission: We Help Our Customers Create Successful Events
column44: As a multi-award winning facility, the Metro Toronto Convention Centre (MTCC) has hosted over 18,000 events and has entertained more than 55 million guests. Kno...wn as a green facility, the Convention Centre endeavours to lead the hospitality industry in a green revolution by providing Sustainable Meeting Solutions. To this end, the MTCC’s South Building has recently been certified as a LEED Gold facility in the Existing Building category.  The Centre has an enviable reputation for food and service excellence. With a new executive chef, a talented culinary team, and a multi-million dollar modernized kitchen equipped with state-of-the-art technology, the Centre brings quality and customization to its food and beverage service.   With more than 600,000 sq ft of exhibit space, including carpeted meeting rooms, two multi-purpose ballrooms, and a beautiful 1,232-seat theatre, it is no wonder more than 600 events are hosted every year.   The MTCC is located in the heart of downtown Toronto, within walking distance of over 11,000 first-class hotel rooms, an impressive underground shopping complex with over 1,200 shops, dynamic restaurants, and world-class city sites. Address: 1046 Deep Cove Road North Vancouver, British Columbia
about: info@musart.ca 604-924-MUS1 (6871)
mission: Musart is a non-profit cultural society for the arts.  Since 1992, its purpose as a society has been to create opportunity and exposure for local Lower Mainland... artists, musicians, dancers and poets with a focus on the North Shore community.  Musart also provides promotion for educational arts programs such as acting, theatre, and music summer camps for children and young adults. See More artists, musicians, dancers and poets with a focus on the North Shore community.  Musart also provides promotion for educational arts programs such as acting, theatre, and music summer camps for children and young adults.
company overview: Musart Cultural Society was established in 1992 to govern over the infamous jazz club, The Glass Slipper, that unfortunately burned down in January 1997.  In th...e fall of 1997, Tyler Pearson took over the Musart Cultural Society to govern over the annual community festival Deep Cove Daze and to continue it's mandate to provide opportunity and exposure for artists in the community.  In the spring of 1998, Tyler found the first funding to hire a coordinator to work on the festival.  Jeff Maynard was the first coordinator.  He approached Tyler with the idea to put on a series of concerts at Cates Park leading up to Deep Cove Daze.  With lots of enthusiasm and little funding, The Cates Park Concert Series was born to support local original music.   Both Deep Cove Daze and The Cates Park Concert Series have now been running under the direction of Tyler Pearson and the Musart Cultural Society for 15 years. Deep Cove Daze will be held on August 27th from 12-8pm, at Panorama Park. Members of the community from all age groups participate in a wide range of activities at Deep Cove Daze.  Multiple stages with live music, dance, performances from magicians and various entertainers, a midway full of rides and many activities for children, over 50 artisans and local merchants booths as well as corporate, environmental and educational booths, various food and beverage concessions including our infamous beer gardens with the “Dave’s Not Here” house band. Provide a place to grab a drink and collaborate with others  Promotion for musicians: three separate stages for artists to perform their music (one inside the shop, one upstairs in our jam space and one in the courtyard out back).  Recording and playing their music (freshly recorded in the upper level) in our café for everyone to hear.  Promote Art by display around the entire place.  In short, we want to provide creative people with an outlet to expand and move forward, to be able to network and further pursue the dream.  Did we mention we make a great cup of coffee? See More 2. Page Types: Performance & Event Venue | Nonprofit Organization | Event Planner
about: A Festival of Music in Historic Nova Scotia
column44: Musique Royale is a not-for-profit organization based in Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, dedicated to promoting traditional and early music in historic venues throughou...t the province. Since its founding in 1985, Musique Royale has continued to celebrate venues of architectural and historic significance, and bring world-class music to communities across the province.  Founded in 1985 by John Grew and a small group of dedicated friends, the French and English overtones in the festival's name were chosen specifically to refer to the presence of more than one cultural force in Nova Scotia’s development, and to pay tribute to the province's diverse musical heritage.  Current Artistic and Managing Director, Barbara Butler, continues to guide the organization in its original mandate, while promoting its growth from a summer festival to include a year-round concert series on the south shore.  One of our main successes is working with volunteers throughout the province in venues of all sizes and histories as well as to promote a sense of community and shared pride in Nova Scotia's rich heritage. It is as much about bringing great traditional and early music to local communities as it is about offering the visiting musicians a taste of Nova Scotia, its landscape, its people, and its historic venues.  Volunteers are at the heart of each event, warmly welcoming local, national, and international musicians and audience members alike to the 20 plus communities partnered with Musique Royale. Our work would not be possible without the generous support of each local community. We gratefully thank them, and all our patrons and sponsors, named and unnamed.  Musique Royale is generously supported by Federal Department of Canadian Heritage, the Nova Scotia Department of Communities, Culture and Heritage, Arts Nova Scotia, the Lloyd Carr Harris Foundation, Music Nova Scotia, season benefactor Peggy Corkum and valued anonymous support.  Whether you are a local resident in a seaside community on the South Shore, or a visiting traveller in the magnificent highlands of Cape Breton, Musique Royale has a concert for you! See Moret the province. about: A beautiful 230-seat concert and live theatre venue situated approximately 45 minutes from Halifax.
column44: The Musquodoboit Valley Bicentennial Theatre and Cultural Centre is a 230-seat restored heritage building (circa 1928) that serves as both theatre venue and com...munity facility in the heart of the Musquodoboit Valley. "The Theatre" as it's been dubbed, is a Halifax Regional Municipality-owned arts facility, which is supported by HRM and operated by a volunteer Board of Directors. The Bicentennial Theatre hosts the annual Robbie Burns Dinner in January and the Kirk Logan Old Time Fiddling Contest each September. We are home to Canadian artist William Gill's 1892 Italianate Garden Scene, a rare piece of restored 19th century stage art which may be viewed on request. Musical entertainment, live theatre, improv, dances, meetings, drama camps and Monday Bingo are all featured in our historic building. See Moremunity facility in the heart of the Musquodoboit Valley. column44: A PROUD PART OF EAST YORK FOR OVER 90 YRS....  Originally founded as a private Veterans' Social Club, The Royal Canadian Legion has grown over the years to beco...me so much more than the stereotype you've been lead to believe...at least at Branch 22.  We're open seven days a week with NO MEMBERSHIP REQUIRED to come on in and join the fun!  All are welcome. All we ask is that you leave your hat...and attitude...at the door, sign in on our Guestbook and ENJOY YOURSELF!   Check our EVENTS section or join our Facebook group (groups/rcl22) for the latest Branch fun and events.  Be one of the first to follow us on twitter and instagram (@MyBranch22)  Looking for an inexpensive location for your event? Check out our rental halls on the 2nd and 3rd floors (not currently accessible) available with or without bar service at reasonable prices. (discounts and rental priority given to Branch 22 Members.) Catering services are also available at additional cost. (Catering beyond simple finger foods are prepared off-site by a local company with a portion of the profits donated to the Branch 22 L.A.) Permission to use the on-site kitchens may be arranged for those providing their own food. Contact the branch by phone during regular business hours or by Facebook PM for details.  **Please note: The Steward may choose to extended hours beyond those posted to accommodate Clubroom activity. Saturday nights where we have live music in the Clubroom, regular closing time is 12 midnight but may be further extended. column44: The New Moon Folk Club is dedicated to the presentation of great live folk music in Edmonton.  In 2015, we were saddened by the Full Moon Folk club’s decision t...o close its doors after 30 years. We decided to do something about it, and start a new club! We run the shows in the same venue, with the same great set-up. 'Same folk, new people'!   The club's revival has been a true community effort. about: Plays well with others.
mission: Neworld uses popular forms to examine our lives in the context of who counts, who doesn’t and what our relationship is to the people we may think we aren’t. Res...ource sharing, creative partnerships and a deep commitment to both the principle and practice of collaboration are central to the work we make. We strive to tell stories that are as complicated and contradictory as the enormously small country we live in. See Moreource sharing, creative partnerships and a deep commitment to both the principle and practice of collaboration are central to the work we make. We strive to tell stories that are as complicated and contradictory as the enormously small country we live in.
company overview: Neworld Theatre is an award-winning, Vancouver-based theatre company that creates, produces and tours new plays and performance events.  The company is led by Artistic Director Marcus Youssef and Artistic Producer Adrienne Wong with Managing Producer, Kirsty Munro
products: How Has My Love Affected You? Winners & Losers Blue Box... The Idiot The Last Days of Judas Iscariot PodPlays Peter Panties Ali & Ali: The Deportation Hearings Are We There Yet?  Mixie and the Halfbreeds  HIVE 2 Nanay  Tideline  My Name is Rachel Corrie No One is Illegal  Crime and Punishment  U.S. Interventions The Adventures of Ali and Ali and the Axes of Evil  The Heretic  An Evening with Richard Rodriguez Placebook  HIVE  Everyone Belly Fish Eyes  Adrift on the Nile  Truth in Testimony The Bloody Cleanup  Asylum of the Universe See More The Idiot The Last Days of Judas Iscariot PodPlays Peter Panties Ali & Ali: The Deportation Hearings Are We There Yet?  Mixie and the Halfbreeds  HIVE 2 Nanay  Tideline  My Name is Rachel Corrie No One is Illegal  Crime and Punishment  U.S. Interventions The Adventures of Ali and Ali and the Axes of Evil  The Heretic  An Evening with Richard Rodriguez Placebook  HIVE  Everyone Belly Fish Eyes  Adrift on the Nile  Truth in Testimony The Bloody Cleanup  Asylum of the Universe
column44: Our mandate is historically rooted in an experience of ethnic and cultural diversity, particularly in relationship to the Middle East. Over the past few seasons... this has broadened into a more comprehensive contention with the central question of human identity, experience and perceptions of difference. Neworld’s founding value since our incorporation in 1994 has been one of diversity and as such we remain committed to providing a platform for multiple artistic voices to wrestle with this notion of difference.  Since 1999, Neworld has won more than 20 Jessie Richardson Theatre Awards (from over 50 nominations), the Alcan Performing Arts Award, the Vancouver Sun Innovation Award, the Seattle Times Footlight Award, and the Canada Council Theatre for Young Audiences Award.   Our shows have been presented by major festivals including the Magnetic North Theatre Festival (Canada's premiere English‐language theatre festival), the PuSh International Performing Arts Festival, and our work has toured locally and to On The Boards in Seattle, WA and the 2008 International Festival of Authors, Brno, Czech Republic. Toured works include include Ali and Ali and the aXes of Evil, Mixie and the Halfbreeds, Adrift, Crime and Punishment and Asylum of the Universe.  In 2009, Neworld also co-founded PL 1422 a cultural hub in East Vancouver co-managed with three other indie theatre companies. Our largest collaborative effort (between 11 organizations) is the Obstructions series, which continues from last season. Inspired in part by The Five Obstructions by Jørgen Leth and Lars Von Trier, Obstructions calls for thoughtful discussions of each company’s individual tendencies toward form, place, style, theme, design, period, and story. Based on this conversation, the core artists of each participating company are given a list of obstructions that prompt them to adapt a new approach to making theatre. (http://progresslab.ca/)  In addition to our mainstage productions, Neworld produces a range of events, from cabaret nights to live readings to public lectures and interviews. We also work closely with community groups, pairing professional artists with non-professionals from different communities to help them create performances that address their self-defined aspirations and concerns.  Neworld is cited by both the National Post and the Globe and Mail as one of the companies driving the nationally recognized renaissance in independent Vancouver theatre   History Neworld Theatre was founded by Artistic Producer Camyar Chai, who conceived the company while at the University of British Columbia, with co-conspirators Mara Coward and Tom Scholte.  Initially, productions were primarily folk-style adaptations of classical Iranian texts and/or myths, reflecting both Camyar's cultural background and the sizeable population of Persian Canadians in the Lower Mainland of Vancouver. These shows developed a strong following in the Iranian-Canadian community, regularly selling out the 250 seat Vancouver East Cultural Centre. Early productions included Love, Quest and Evening in a Strange Land.  Numerous productions of the multiple-award winning plays about Mordecai Vanunu by Camyar Chai and Mara Coward, and a national tour of the show with Rumble Productions (www.rumble.org), marked the company's first foray into non-didactic, politically-engaged productions and national touring, both of which have become company signatures.  Devil Box Cabaret (1999), a site-specific collective creation based on the play The Four Boxes by Iranian writer Bahram Beyzaee, marked both a move toward a more hybridized performance style and Neworld's full emergence as a significant company in the independent theatre scene. Winning numerous awards and selling out its run, Devil Box anticipated the move to site-specific work that has dominated recent independent Vancouver theatre.  For the next three years (1999 – 2002) the company produced the Leaky Heaven Circus. What was meant to be a 'one-off' millennium project became a four-show phenomenon that culminated in the formation of a new company, The Leaky Heaven Performance Society (www.leakyheaven.com).  In 2005, longtime Neworld associate Marcus Youssef became an Artistic Producer, and Adrienne Wong joined as co-artistic producer soon after. In 2007, Camyar took on a new challenge as Executive Director of Leave Out Violence (LOVE) BC, and Marcus and Adrienne engaged Managing Producer Kirsty Munro.  Since then, Camyar moved on the position as artistic coordinator of the Richmond Cultural Centre. At Neworld, Marcus is now artistic director with Adrienne Wong as artistic producer and Kirsty as managing producer.  The company continues its tradition of collaboration and commitment to exploring difference from multiple perspectives and voices. See More this has broadened into a more comprehensive contention with the central question of human identity, experience and perceptions of difference. Neworld’s founding value since our incorporation in 1994 has been one of diversity and as such we remain committed to providing a platform for multiple artistic voices to wrestle with this notion of difference.  Since 1999, Neworld has won more than 20 Jessie Richardson Theatre Awards (from over 50 nominations), the Alcan Performing Arts Award, the Vancouver Sun Innovation Award, the Seattle Times Footlight Award, and the Canada Council Theatre for Young Audiences Award.   Our shows have been presented by major festivals including the Magnetic North Theatre Festival (Canada's premiere English‐language theatre festival), the PuSh International Performing Arts Festival, and our work has toured locally and to On The Boards in Seattle, WA and the 2008 International Festival of Authors, Brno, Czech Republic. Toured works include include Ali and Ali and the aXes of Evil, Mixie and the Halfbreeds, Adrift, Crime and Punishment and Asylum of the Universe.  In 2009, Neworld also co-founded PL 1422 a cultural hub in East Vancouver co-managed with three other indie theatre companies. Our largest collaborative effort (between 11 organizations) is the Obstructions series, which continues from last season. Inspired in part by The Five Obstructions by Jørgen Leth and Lars Von Trier, Obstructions calls for thoughtful discussions of each company’s individual tendencies toward form, place, style, theme, design, period, and story. Based on this conversation, the core artists of each participating company are given a list of obstructions that prompt them to adapt a new approach to making theatre. (http://progresslab.ca/)  In addition to our mainstage productions, Neworld produces a range of events, from cabaret nights to live readings to public lectures and interviews. We also work closely with community groups, pairing professional artists with non-professionals from different communities to help them create performances that address their self-defined aspirations and concerns. The company continues its tradition of collaboration and commitment to exploring difference from multiple perspectives and voices.

about: A booking agency based in the North of England.
biography: NMC Live is a booking agency based in the North of England, focusing on European and Worldwide touring for artists within various sub-genres of rock and metal m...usic. The company is part of the group formed around Northern Music, a management company established in 1988 that represents Opeth, Devin Townsend, Paradise Lost and more. In line with the NMC ethos, we aim to develop long-term, international careers in the live field for our artists.  Although our pedigree is in rock music, we provide a far-reaching and professional bookings solution for artists from a variety of genres. We understand the need for our artists to play a diverse range of venues and events in order to reach and develop new fans and experience new environments. We believe that artists should not be confined to one audience base, and that they should be able to crossover into new areas to continue their development and growth.  We work closely with all sizes of venues, promoters, events and festivals so that we can provide the best possible personalised service for the artists that we work with. Not only will we provide the link to a trusted network of promoters, we will also be unerring in keeping our finger on the pulse by constantly expanding our database, propelled by our belief that the live arena is - and always will be - absolutely essential to the future of music. about: Le restaurant Normandie est une institution établie en Beauce depuis plus de 75 ans.
column44: Le restaurant Normandie est une institution établie en Beauce depuis plus de 75 ans. Un peu d’histoire… C’est en 1939 que fut construit ce petit restaurant de v...illage (environ 40 places) appelé à l’époque le «Café bleu».  Quelques propriétaires ce sont, par la suite, succédés dont M. Marquis Fortin en 1986. Ce dernier a fait beaucoup de modifications dont un agrandissement majeur pour ne nommer que celui-ci . En 1999, le restaurant Normandie fut incendié et déclaré perte totale. Historique complet: Conseiller municipal de Beauceville-Est de 1942 à 1952, M. Pierre Rodrigue en a vu de l’eau couler sous les ponts en 83 ans! Il est l’homme derrière la construction de l’édifice du restaurant Normandie en septembre 1939 alors qu’il n’avait que 23 ans. Le bâtiment n’avait que deux étages et le restaurant se nommait alors le «Café bleu», nom qu’il a porté jusqu’en 1950, alors que les propriétaires étaient M. et Mme Marcel Fortin. Par la suite,  M. Laurent Veilleux s’est porté acquéreur de la bâtisse et c’est à ce moment que le restaurant devenait officiellement le Normandie. Un an plus tard, il vendait l’établissement à son frère Charles-Émile, aujourd’hui décédé. Sa veuve, Mme Marie- Jeanne Veilleux habitait la maison voisine du restaurant. Elle a donc vu s’envoler en fumée le restaurant qu’ils ont tenu de 1950 à 1986 alors que M. Marquis Fortin en devenait le propriétaire. «Ça fait mal de voir partir en fumée quelque chose que l’on a construit», souligne M. Rodrigue qui se rappelle qu’à cette époque, on ne payait le café que 0,10 $ et qu’on pouvait dîner pour 0,60 $. Il ajoute, en riant, avoir vendu, en 1937, 10 vaches pour 100 $ et qu’aujourd’hui on débourse facilement plus de 1,500 $ pour une seule de ces bêtes. C’est une partie de la petite histoire de Beauceville qui disparaît avec cet incendie précise M. Rodrigue qui se remémore la belle époque, alors que Beauceville comptait plus de 6 000 habitants et Saint-Georges n’était qu’un petit village. mission: The mandate of NLFB is to present music, performing and creative arts through its annual three day music festival and year round activities that support the reg...ional artistic and musical talent in Northern Ontario. The goals adopted to achieve this are:   1) Commitment to reflect the cultural diversity of Northern Ontario in its operations and programming;   2) Commitment to treat all performers and their work with dignity, respect, and fairness;   3) Commitment to develop, support and acknowledge the value of local artists and performers;   4) Commitment to develop support and honour the work of volunteers;   5) Commitment to develop, support and acknowledge the interests of its audiences and developing their appreciation of the arts;   6) Commitment to build links with the community through cooperation and partnerships with other arts and cultural organizations, umbrella groups and other community groups;   7) Commitment to operate in a fiscally responsible manner with the goal of financial self-sufficiency. See Moreional artistic and musical talent in Northern Ontario. company overview: NLFB Is Canada's longest continually running out door music festival. Over the years, the festival has grown from a single day 'folk festival' into a seasoned p...resenter of roots, indie, world and modern music. It has become known as the signature music & arts festival of the North. NLFB has a mandate to book a certain amount of Aboriginal, francophone and other multicultural content each year, in line with the regional population. The organization also presents several other concerts, events and competitions throughout the year. column44: Buying Tickets  If tickets are available, you can get them through our website, Ticketmaster or by stopping by the venue Box Office....  Visit Ticketmaster: www.ticketmaster.co.uk  The venue Box Office opens from 4pm until 6pm, and from 6.30pm until 9.30pm, on show days ONLY.  Tickets are also available from O2 Academy Islington (12pm - 4pm Monday - Saturday) and O2 Academy Brixton (open from 2 hours before doors on show days only).  There's a £1 booking fee for cash sales and £1.50 booking fee for card sales.  BEWARE OF SECONDARY TICKETING (Touts, eBay, Seatwave, GetMeIn, Viagogo, Stubhub etc). Fraudulent tickets such as cancelled & duplicated tickets can be sold on the secondary ticketing market. The venue is unable to help with ticketing problems unless tickets are purchased with authorized ticketing agents.  *************************************************************************  Where to eat  Westfield also boasts an impressive range of eateries, such as Gourmet Burger Kitchen (which in our opinion does the best burgers in the world), Nando's, Bamboo Basket, Del'Aziz, Fire & Stone, Bill’s, The Real Greek, Wagamama & loads more. uk.westfield.com/london  Away from Westfiled, there's a good selection of places to eat and drink nearby. Here's some we recommend:  ||Al Forno (Italian) - Shop 3/4 Romney Court, Shepherds Bush Green, W12 8PY - 020 8746 1433 Authentic Italian restaurant with a beautiful setting. Gorgeous food and friendly staff. Perfect pre-gig stop off!  ||Tatra Restaurant (Polish) - 24 Goldhawk Road,  W12 8DH -  020 8749 8193  Highly regarded Polish restaurant. Watch out for those vodka shots though...  O2 Empire customers receive 3 courses from the a la carte menu for £15 upon showing their ticket for that evenings show.  ||Aroma (Oriental) - First Floor West 12 Shopping Centre (Opposite Shepherds Bush Central Line Station) - 020 8746 7625 All you can eat buffet with a selection of 85 dishes for dinner including Popular South East and Asian dishes, Sushi, Teppanyaki and homemade desserts.  ||Liz Café - 7 Goldhawk Road, London W12 8QQ - 07984 660358 Family run business serving fresh home-cooked pastas, sandwiches and salads. They also have a selection of home-made cakes to accompany our great coffee and teas.  There's a wealth of pubs and bars in the vicinity too. The following all serve food and are only short hop from the venue:  ||The Sindercombe Social - 2 Goldhawk Road, W12 8QD Our lovely new next door neighbours.Pop up diner every day until 10pm.  2-4-1 burgers on Tuesdays and a roast on Sunday - can't go wrong!  ||The Defector's Weld - 170 Uxbridge Road, W12 8AA  According to Time Out, “You won't find a pub much better than this west of Soho”. And frankly it's hard to disagree.  ||The Green - 172-174 Uxbridge Road, W12 7JP (neighbor across the street to The Defector's Weld!) A modern bar with big windows- just perfect for people watching...  Needless to say, we have McDonalds and KFC. There's also a Wetherspoons (in the West 12 shopping centre opposite central line station).  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to eat after  Bagel Bite (on the Green) is a very popular late night snack.    >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to go after  The following watering holes remain open late on Friday and Saturday nights:  The Green - until 1am The Defector's Weld - until 2am  (Locations above!)  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to get cash  O2 Shepherd's Bush Empire has a cash machine located in the foyer. The Post Office and Barclay's Bank is just a few doors down from us and there are plenty of banks / cashpoints around the Green.   *************************************************************************  Where to get a taxi from  Our neighbours Sunshine Mini Cabs (located immediately adjacent to our loading bay). 020 8749 6000  Please never take a mini cab off the street.  Be CABWISE: text home to 60835  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to get a night bus from  There are bus stops right outside the O2 Shepherd's Bush Empire, and along the north side of the Green. Please check with TfL for the right stop for your destination.   *************************************************************************  Where to stay   We have a lot of nice hotels in the area, so if you are coming from outside of London or even abroad or just want to have a big night out with some drinks, why not stay in one of them. The Dorsett, Hotel Ibis & K West Hotel & Spa are some of the better known hotels, but there is also some lovely rooms in the few independent hotels nearby such as the Grantly Hotel (50-51 Shepherd's Bush Green, London W12 8PS - 020 8743 4345)  *************************************************************************  What else is there to do in the area  Firstly, the Westfield Shopping Centre is literally a few minutes away. If you have some time to spare before doors open, we recommend a shopping spree (although don't go too crazy, you've got to carry those bags all night!)  There is also other theatres and music venues in the area, we recommend:  ||Bush Theatre - 7 Uxbridge Road, London W12 8LJ - 020 8743 5050 Check out their event listings here bushtheatre.co.uk  ||Bush Hall - 310 Uxbridge Road, London W12 7LJ - 020 8222 6955 Check out their event listings here bushhallmusic.co.uk  *************************************************************************  STREET TEAM  FREE ENTRY TO GIGS!!! Join our Street Team to get into gigs for free. Go to <a href="https://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.academystreetteam.co.uk%2F%3Ffbclid%3DIwAR0ua3CD-helBB_0J4uL_QqWBEBR7lltAjtoyTbtEE1PHIIsJ5jfmJ18c1k&h=AT2QwYqvHbEarhfkWR80IVdZKSpBXmq96Ge-KqcSXLSksYsm8PQpZdFkRaO1UJUJMNlATmc9fOhxYnzNoI93XSyjGFznMN_fRj_ukvZDDntB5tjQeVTF7LlfcExl5OfaVJiXy0JP" target="_blank" data-ft="{"tn":"-U"}" rel="noopener nofollow" data-lynx-mode="asynclazy">www.academystreetteam.co.uk to register.  Follow our Tweets and Instagram For Exclusive Ticket Giveaways, Latest News and General Musings. <a href="https://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Ftwitter.com%2Fo2sbe%3Ffbclid%3DIwAR0Z1wTSKZq9xcgAOIYqwzbR7Nq1jjIKl6kyx14jBr-6ttMAt37qvK8m_rk&h=AT12WBdGmP1kyvclnYHCBWj3NDT1ADgizp_hTHQ_uazWZCVCHN2YX_J1YLV1NuFrd1uvcUgx4lbXxTuYukGp2ej4FV0lUOL6VwTA5BssR-BTC-8cS5thM3ONECDOZzUEIw6dlBr5" target="_blank" data-ft="{"tn":"-U"}" rel="noopener nofollow" data-lynx-mode="asynclazy">twitter.com/o2sbe <a href="https://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Finstagram.com%2Fo2sbe%3Ffbclid%3DIwAR2TAVrgHxD0qx9bgESltHT5RFP-Fx59-CXxy58sNSJcNvg-ePvG-J18zJM&h=AT0j0LuF4O_cb5OO-PWutkNcMxBB8RZLbqs8lzCWVP-iP7d58wZLN3YV2v_gI3dp21hu0-V0qAf8nLIvKhN3R7gyjzl90iRlrnkJVgEebEt2I7KErMJ3fI7YFwaCm_2iUMyj0VJu" target="_blank" data-ft="{"tn":"-U"}" rel="noopener nofollow" data-lynx-mode="asynclazy">instagram.com/o2sbe <span class="text_exposed_link"><a class="see_more_link" onclick="var func = function(e) { e.preventDefault(); }; var parent = Parent.byClass(this, "text_exposed_root"); if (parent && parent.getAttribute("id") == "id_5ebef0c936f6e3e97448597") { CSS.addClass(parent, "text_exposed"); Arbiter.inform("reflow"); }; func(event); " data-ft="{"tn":"e"}" href="#" role="button"><span class="see_more_link_inner">See More  Visit Ticketmaster: www.ticketmaster.co.uk  The venue Box Office opens from 4pm until 6pm, and from 6.30pm until 9.30pm, on show days ONLY.  Tickets are also available from O2 Academy Islington (12pm - 4pm Monday - Saturday) and O2 Academy Brixton (open from 2 hours before doors on show days only).  There's a £1 booking fee for cash sales and £1.50 booking fee for card sales.  BEWARE OF SECONDARY TICKETING (Touts, eBay, Seatwave, GetMeIn, Viagogo, Stubhub etc). Fraudulent tickets such as cancelled & duplicated tickets can be sold on the secondary ticketing market. The venue is unable to help with ticketing problems unless tickets are purchased with authorized ticketing agents.  *************************************************************************  Where to eat  Westfield also boasts an impressive range of eateries, such as Gourmet Burger Kitchen (which in our opinion does the best burgers in the world), Nando's, Bamboo Basket, Del'Aziz, Fire & Stone, Bill’s, The Real Greek, Wagamama & loads more. uk.westfield.com/london  Away from Westfiled, there's a good selection of places to eat and drink nearby. Here's some we recommend:  ||Al Forno (Italian) - Shop 3/4 Romney Court, Shepherds Bush Green, W12 8PY - 020 8746 1433 Authentic Italian restaurant with a beautiful setting. Gorgeous food and friendly staff. Perfect pre-gig stop off!  ||Tatra Restaurant (Polish) - 24 Goldhawk Road,  W12 8DH -  020 8749 8193  Highly regarded Polish restaurant. Watch out for those vodka shots though...  O2 Empire customers receive 3 courses from the a la carte menu for £15 upon showing their ticket for that evenings show.  ||Aroma (Oriental) - First Floor West 12 Shopping Centre (Opposite Shepherds Bush Central Line Station) - 020 8746 7625 All you can eat buffet with a selection of 85 dishes for dinner including Popular South East and Asian dishes, Sushi, Teppanyaki and homemade desserts.  ||Liz Café - 7 Goldhawk Road, London W12 8QQ - 07984 660358 Family run business serving fresh home-cooked pastas, sandwiches and salads. They also have a selection of home-made cakes to accompany our great coffee and teas.  There's a wealth of pubs and bars in the vicinity too. The following all serve food and are only short hop from the venue:  ||The Sindercombe Social - 2 Goldhawk Road, W12 8QD Our lovely new next door neighbours.Pop up diner every day until 10pm.  2-4-1 burgers on Tuesdays and a roast on Sunday - can't go wrong!  ||The Defector's Weld - 170 Uxbridge Road, W12 8AA  According to Time Out, “You won't find a pub much better than this west of Soho”. And frankly it's hard to disagree.  ||The Green - 172-174 Uxbridge Road, W12 7JP (neighbor across the street to The Defector's Weld!) A modern bar with big windows- just perfect for people watching...  Needless to say, we have McDonalds and KFC. There's also a Wetherspoons (in the West 12 shopping centre opposite central line station).  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to eat after  Bagel Bite (on the Green) is a very popular late night snack.    >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to go after  The following watering holes remain open late on Friday and Saturday nights:  The Green - until 1am The Defector's Weld - until 2am  (Locations above!)  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>  Where to get cash  O2 Shepherd's Bush Empire has a cash machine located in the foyer. The Post Office and Barclay's Bank is just a few doors down from us and there are plenty of banks / cashpoints around the Green.   *************************************************************************  Where to get a taxi from  Our neighbours Sunshine Mini Cabs (located immediately adjacent to our loading bay). 020 8749 6000  Please never take a mini cab off the street. about: A new home for live music, creative events and clubnights in London Bridge’s refreshed railway arches.
column44: A new home for live music, creative events and clubnights in London Bridge’s newly refreshed railway arches.    With the sites heritage seeped in a background o...f music and late night parties, OMEARA will be carrying on the baton with a lovingly curated line-up of events, put together by the good people at Communion Music. We’ll be providing a creative events space for everything from the best emerging live acts to renowned DJ’s right in the heart of London.  Our pop-up friends in the arch next door offer a huge variety of top quality food. You can grab yourself a bite to eat, see us at the bar, get a booth with your friends or come and check out the show that night.   Carry on into the early hours with our line-up of clubnights, drinks deals and our late licensed outdoor terrace. We’re only 5 minutes from London Bridge, Southwark and Bermondsey stations, and a 10 minute stroll from Waterloo.   There’s no excuse not to come along for a tipple or two. Whether that’s in the daytime, evening or early morning, that’s up to you... about: Le tout premier restaurant au Canada qui vous invite à vivre l’expérience d’une bonne table et de conversations agréables comme jamais auparavant dans le noir!
public transit: Métro Sherbrooke
column44: O.NOIR va plus loin que seulement stimuler l’imagination et les sens. Après avoir passé quelques heures dans la noirceur totale, les clients comprennent mieux c...e que c’est que vivre avec une déficience visuelle, tout comme le personnel de service du restaurant. * O.NOIR does more than just fire the imagination and stimulate the senses. After a few hours in complete darkness (that’s right, no flashlights, matches, cell phones, cigarette lighters or luminous watches), customers gain a better understanding of what it’s like to be visually impaired – just like the restaurants’ entire wait staff. See Moree que c’est que vivre avec une déficience visuelle, tout comme le personnel de service du restaurant. * O.NOIR does more than just fire the imagination and stimulate the senses. After a few hours in complete darkness (that’s right, no flashlights, matches, cell phones, cigarette lighters or luminous watches), customers gain a better understanding of what it’s like to be visually impaired – just like the restaurants’ entire wait staff.

Address: 356 ave du Mont-Royal Est Montreal, Quebec
about: Salle de spectacles- gallerie d'art
public transit: métro Mont Royal
column44: (English version follows)  _________________________________________________________________________________________________...  Le secteur du plateau Mont-Royal foisonne d’activités artistiques des plus diverses. Malgré toute cette énergie les lieux adéquats, accessibles et propices à la diffusion, manquent à la plupart des créateurs. Partant de ce constat nous avons travaillé au développement d’une salle au-dessus du BÍLÝ KUN (www.bilykun.com).   C’est avec le goût de l’aventure et le désir d’offrir un espace culturel de qualité qu’O PATRO VYS est né en 2003.   O PATRO VYS :Traduction tchèque de ” Au niveau supérieur “.   O PATRO VYS est un organisme à but non lucratif, sa mission étant de diffuser et de promouvoir les créations artistiques locales issues de milieux diversifiés.   O PATRO VYS est une salle multifonctionnelle, un lieu qui s’aménage et s’adapte selon les différentes créations présentées.   SPECTACLES DE MUSIQUES DIVERSES  PERFORMANCES (DANSE,THEATRE,MULTIMEDIA)  EXPOSITIONS ET VERNISSAGES  PROJECTIONS DE COURTS ET LONGS MÉTRAGES  LANCEMENTS  LECTURES ET CAUSERIES  CONFÉRENCES DE PRESSE  RÉCEPTIONS PRIVÉES   L’équipe d’O PATRO VYS se fera un plaisir de vous aiguiller dans la réalisation de vos projets en mettant toutes ses ressources à votre disposition.   _________________________________________________________________________________________________  The Mont-Royal “plateau” neighborhood is overflowing with artistic activities of all kinds. Despite this vibe, adequate and accessible spaces for presenting artistic projects are lacking. As a result, we decided to work towards creating a place, above from the BILY KUN (www.bilykun.com), to fill this void.   O PATRO VÝS— was born in 2003 from our desire to offer a quality space to promote and support the arts.   O PATRO VÝS— Czech for, “The next level “   O PATRO VÝS— is a non-profit organization. Our mission is to promote and present a diverse mix of local artistic creations   O PATRO VÝS— Is a multi-functional space; a space that can be configured and adapted to the needs of the different projects presented.   EXHIBITIONS AND VERNISSAGES  MUSIC  THEATRE  DANCE  MULTI-MEDIA PERFORMANCES  CINEMA  CD AND BOOK LAUNCHES  LECTURES AND FORUMS  PRESS CONFERENCES  PRIVATE RECEPTIONS   The O PATRO VYS team will be pleased to aid you in realizing your projects by putting all our resources at your disposal. about: Open Studios is one part media art, part music, with a little bit of party. Some people even work here!
public transit: Science World/Terminal Skytrain Station
column44: Through its history Open Studios has hosted a number of artists, collectives and arts groups that have been instrumental in the electronic music and media scene... within Vancouver and beyond. Having housed the likes of organizations such as the New Forms Festival, Wagon Repair, Bent Matter, We Have Friends, Homebreakin and Mainsocial, as well as the studio for such artists and community members as Mathew Jonson, Todd Shillington, Ben Nevile, Mario Glavacic, Ben Reeder, Jesse Fisk, Malcolm Levy, Mike McSuede, James Boatman, Cedric Meister, Josh Bartholomew, Jonny Aiello, Matt Reeder, Genki Neshida, Craig Mullin and Neighbour the studio has been a mainstay of the city for the past 10 years. In addition the studio has hosted hundreds of events involving artists from around the globe, local film productions, artist run centres and collectives. See More within Vancouver and beyond. Having housed the likes of organizations such as the New Forms Festival, Wagon Repair, Bent Matter, We Have Friends, Homebreakin and Mainsocial, as well as the studio for such artists and community members as Mathew Jonson, Todd Shillington, Ben Nevile, Mario Glavacic, Ben Reeder, Jesse Fisk, Malcolm Levy, Mike McSuede, James Boatman, Cedric Meister, Josh Bartholomew, Jonny Aiello, Matt Reeder, Genki Neshida, Craig Mullin and Neighbour the studio has been a mainstay of the city for the past 10 years. about: In the heart of Orillia stands a fairy-tale building. Since 1895, the City has dreamed, laughed, wept, celebrated and fought inside the Orillia Opera House
column44: In the very heart of Orillia sits a fairy-tale building, and inside that building, legends are born.   For over 117 years, the City has dreamed, laughed, wept a...nd fought inside the Orillia Opera House. Many of the City’s defining moments have taken place under its landmark twin spires.   Not long after Orillia became a village, residents began to think about moving the market from its location near the waterfront. After a few years of debate, a landowner named Goldwin Smith agreed to donate a half-acre lot on the northwest corner of Mississaga and West Streets. In return, the Village had to clear Mississaga Street West of stumps so Smith could subdivide another parcel of his land up the street.   Some people in the Village wanted nothing more than a good large shed and a few stalls put up in the market for farmers. But the Village Councillors wanted a new town hall to replace the Temperance Hall and a proper lock-up for the rowdies that plagued their lumber town. Arguments over the building of the hall delayed its opening, and Council finally had its first meeting in the new hall August 7, 1874. This Town Hall and lock-up served well from 1874 to 1877. Council again decided something grander was needed for both the shed and town hall, and after a few false starts, tenders were called for, based on plans prepared by the Toronto architectural firm of Gordon and Halliwell and the Opera House was completed in 1895. It cost taxpayers $25,000 and held the Council Chamber, auditorium, City Hall offices, market stalls and eventually the lock-up.  The Opera House, described as “the finest building for corporation purposes of any town in Ontario”, became an immediate source of pride for Orillia. The auditorium had 905 seats with an exquisite wrap around balcony common to the formal Opera Houses of Europe, which might have contributed to its name.   Unfortunately, fire broke out in July 6, 1915 and destroyed most of the building. The last of the debentures for the building had just been paid and Orillians did not want to pay much more for a new theatre. Council had to get the taxpayers’ approval to borrow large amounts of money in those days. The Toronto firm of Burke, Horwood and White was retained to prepare plans for the reconstruction. Council and the Board of Trade pushed for a By-law authorizing a $50,000 debenture to rebuild the Opera House, but residents voted it down. It was too much to spend on a theatre in times of war. The next year’s Council tried for a smaller plan, costing taxpayers $35,000, and it was approved.   The work was completed in 1917. The tall tower on the south side was not rebuilt. The Council Chamber was relocated on the west. A new lobby and stairs were added on the east between the two towers, and restrooms were added to the ground floor. The roof and design of the Opera House were changed. The wrap around “Opera House” balcony was replaced with a deeper balcony facing the stage. The dressing rooms were moved downstairs so the stage occupied the entire width of the building. A small, shallow orchestra pit and exterior backstage hoist were added.   In 1958 a new entrance was constructed on the east end of the building and many attempts to bring the front of the building back to its original beauty have yet to be realized. Renovations in the 1980’s brought upgrades to the public areas with a public elevator and air conditioning. Remedial structure work was undertaken, smoke pockets were installed and a lighting bridge was added to the auditorium.  The 700 seat auditorium was also a movie house from the 20’s until the late 50’s. It was a favourite place on a Saturday for a kid to spend an afternoon for a quarter.   The Opera House, known for its fine acoustics and has featured such artists as the Marx Brothers, Glenn Gould, Oscar Peterson, k.d. lang, Mickey Rooney, Dan Hill, Liona Boyd, Blue Rodeo, George Canyon, Paul Brandt, Ron James, Manteca, Lighthouse, The Stampeders and our own hometown boy, Gordon Lightfoot. As well as, many would-be greats such as school bands and local theatre groups. The Council Chamber was moved in 1997 to the newly renovated Tudhope building, now the Orillia City Centre. This gave the Opera House space for a small theatre, known as the “Studio” with 108 seats.  On October 18, 1997 the Orillia Opera House renamed its auditorium in honour of its most famous son. Gordon Lightfoot has performed here since he was a child and has continued the tradition of playing here, usually as a benefit, to the present day.  Since 1895 the Orillia Opera House has been bringing the best in local, national and international talent to its stages. From performances by living legends to our popular summer theatre series, there is always something happening that will entertain, educate and inspire.  Managed by the City’s Department of Parks, Recreation and Culture. The Orillia Opera House continues to inspire those that are great and those that will be, while renovations and capital projects continue to keep the fairy tale alive. The Osprey is the arts performance hub of Shelburne County. Offering an intimate & inviting, fully-equipped theatre venue, we present a full season of live music, theatre, dance, art exhibits, films, youth events, workshops, day camps & community events.
column44: The Osprey is the arts performance hub of Shelburne County. Offering an intimate and inviting, fully-equipped theatre venue with retractable soft seating, the O...sprey is multi-purpose and adaptable. Each year we present a full season of live music, live theatre, live dance as well as art exhibits, film screenings, youth performances, book launches, workshops, day camps and community events.  The Osprey also hosts events across Shelburne County in schools and other venues and rents its space to community groups and private concerns for public and private functions such as weddings, meetings, conferences and lectures.  The Osprey Arts Centre Association is run by a volunteer Board of Directors and three part-time staff.  Mission Statement: To manage the Osprey Arts Centre as a fiscally sound theatre dedicated to excellence in the arts, and to make it a true community performing arts centre available to and providing programs of artistic merit for everyone in Shelburne County.  Vision Statement: The Osprey Arts Centre vision sees a community where all members, youth, adult and senior, and culturally diverse, have access to high quality performing arts events, both amateur and professional. To be a place where people turn for training in the arts and to be available to all members of the community as a place to perform. The Osprey Arts Centre aims to be a true community arts crossroad so that the people of Shelburne County recognize the value of and appreciate the presence of the performing arts in their community.  Values: The members of the Osprey Arts Centre Association (OACA), and in particular, the board of directors are guided in making decisions by the following values.  1. The OACA values artistic experimentation, excellence in art, and creativity.  2. The OACA values good financial management based on balanced budgets, clear record keeping and financial reporting, and responsible management of resources.  3. The OACA is responsible to its community and values sharing with other community organizations for the cultural development of Shelburne County.  4. The OACA respects people and is committed to creating safe working environments. As an employer, OACA values cultural diversity, dedication to its values, motivation to continue to grow and develop its objectives, and fairmindedness in its dealings with each other and the public which it serves. about: Ottawa's hottest summer music festival!  July 8-18, 2021. Located in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
column44: Ottawa Bluesfest has been ranked by Billboard Magazine as one of the top-10 most successful outdoor music festivals in the world. People travel from far and wid...e to attend the 'fest, and music fans in Ottawa look forward to opening night with mounting anticipation, year after year. This award winning, multi-staged music extravaganza is the biggest outdoor music festival in Canada and is considered one of the most important music events in North America. Thousands of national and international performers are featured annually at LeBreton Flats Park, in downtown Ottawa. Address: St Andrew's Church, 82 Kent Street Ottawa, Ontario
about: An annual family oriented celebration of folk music, dance, and spoken word: April 23-26, 2020
public transit: We are steps from the Lyon station on the Confederation Line
column44: Welcome to the Ottawa Grassroots Festival. Looking forward to our 9th year, we are a family-friendly, volunteer run, not-for-profit music festival that happens ...every April.  It is a joyful celebration that will launch you into Spring.  People tell us the festival was so much fun that we will be expanding to three days instead of two. The next festival is April 23-36, 2020 and will take place at St Andrews Church on Kent Street. Our daytime programming is free.  Events start at noon and there will be more of everything: participatory workshops, kid-friendly activities, short concerts (45 minutes) with really intriguing artists, jam sessions and singalongs.  The evenings will be ticketed concerts, which start at 7:30, and will be every bit as exciting as before.  Please join this FaceBook page to stay in touch. Over the coming months, we will keep you posted as we firm up the artists and program details.  And check out our web page (http://ottawagrassrootsfestival.com) and sign up for our e-mail newsletter on the website. If you are a fan of The Ottawa Grassroots Festival, don’t be shy to friend us and invite your friends and family.  Grassroots wants you. Attend. Volunteer. Participate. Enjoy. See Moreevery April. Over the coming months, we will keep you posted as we firm up the artists and program details.  And check out our web page (http://ottawagrassrootsfestival.com) and sign up for our e-mail newsletter on the website. If you are a fan of The Ottawa Grassroots Festival, don’t be shy to friend us and invite your friends and family.  Grassroots wants you. Attend. Volunteer. Participate. Enjoy.

about: Professional in style, traditional in tone, Ottawa Little Theatre has been a vital part of the Ottawa arts community for more than a century.
column44: Professional in style, traditional in tone, Ottawa Little Theatre (OLT) has been a vital part of the Ottawa arts community for over 100 years, making it the old...est on-going community theatre in North America. With a 462-seat licensed auditorium and lobby, OLT is anything but “little”. Between 50,000 and 60,000 patrons walk through our doors each season to enjoy OLT’s plays, special events and more.  OLT has produced over 1,000 plays in our first century. All directors, designers, actors and stage crew are volunteers. As a charitable not-for-profit, volunteer-based organization, OLT relies on its subscribers, ticket buyers and individual donors to provide nearly 70% of its income.    OLT has a long and illustrious history, and many of the actors who stood on the OLT stage have gone on to successful careers in film and television, and continue to do so! about: L'aissez les bon temps rouler… ( Let the good times roll )
column44: Welcome to the Ouisi Bistro, Vancouver`s original New Orleans restaurant. For over 16 years The Ouisi Bistro has been proudly serving authentic Cajun-Creole cui...sine. The restaurant is located in South Granville and is a great pre-theatre or post shopping meeting place. The dishes are rustic and down home comfort food with creative twists. By emphasising local ingredients and traditional southern fare the Ouisi offers the flavours and excitement of New Orleans, presented without pretension in a warm, engaging atmosphere. Try the Ale Marinated Chicken and Hot Smoked Duck Sausage Gumbo. To accompany our cuisine, taste one of the 60 plus ' Beers from around the World ', choose a selection from our wine list, have a taste of one of seven beers on tap, drink a Sazerac, or find your favourite  among our immense single malt scotch and bourbon menu. During the season, escape to a cozy hidden patio, where you can enjoy our fabulous brunch or lunch menu. Nothing beats a 14th Street Eats and a cold Stella while outside amongst the ivy and japanese maple. Whether you enjoy the dining room with it`s frescoed ceiling and jazz inspired walls, relax in the outdoor garden courtyard, sip a mint julep while dining along the front window watching the street scape or pony up to the unique copper and reclaimed fir bar, you are sure to experience the passion and hospitality of an evening in New Orleans. Come on in and : l'aissez les bon temps roulez!" Let the good times roll..... See Moresine. The restaurant is located in South Granville and is a great pre-theatre or post shopping meeting place. Act Name: Pacific Gateway Marina + Bridgemans West Coast Eatery
Address: 17110 Parkinson Rd Port Renfrew, British Columbia
about: Our fishing focused marina and restaurant are a must stop along the Pacific Marine Circle Route
column44: Our fishing focused marina is located in Port Renfrew a community on the west coast of Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada, located about a 2-hour drive ...west of Victoria, British Columbia. The marina is a full service marina open from May 1st until September 15th. From the marina fisherman come for some of the best fishing on Vancouver Island including Swiftsure Bank an hour run from Port Renfrew, The Beach, and East Point, Can Buoy: just a short trip minutes outside Port Renfrew harbour. Our plans are to work with the community to make the marina open full time and offer extended moorage and breakwaters. See Morewest of Victoria, British Columbia. The marina is a full service marina open from May 1st until September 15th. From the marina fisherman come for some of the best fishing on Vancouver Island including Swiftsure Bank an hour run from Port Renfrew, The Beach, and East Point, Can Buoy: just a short trip minutes outside Port Renfrew harbour. Our plans are to work with the community to make the marina open full time and offer extended moorage and breakwaters.

Le Palace de Granby existe depuis plus de 50 ans.  Il accueille annuellement plus de 120 000 spectateurs.
column44: Le Palace de Granby présente plus de 100 spectacles annuellement, et ce, dans toutes les disciplines. Le Palace est l'hôte du prestigieux Festival International... de la Chanson de Granby et agit activement dans le développement touristique de la région en présentant un spectacle majeur lors de la saison estivale.  Le Palace répond activement à un besoin de divertissement pour l'ensemble de la population de Granby et de la région. La réponse du public étant toujours présente, on ne peut que remercier tous les gens qui font le succès du Palace.   La Nétiquette  Il nous fait plaisir de vous accueillir sur notre page Facebook. Nous aimons lire vos commentaires, vos publications et vos partages. Par contre, tous commentaires ne respectant pas la Nétiquette seront supprimés sans préavis. Si un utilisateur ne respecte pas cette Nétiquette plus d’une fois, il sera bloqué de la page. general information: Les commentaires et conversations sur les plateformes de communication du Palais Montcalm – Maison de la musique sont précieux et très appréciés. Bien utilisés,... ces outils de communication permettent les échanges et le partage avec la communauté, ainsi que l’amélioration de l’offre culturelle. Le non-respect de la nétiquette peut mener, selon le niveau de gravité ou la fréquence des écarts de conduite, de la modération des contenus à la suspension des accès d’un utilisateur, et ce, sans préavis. mission: Le Palais Montcalm a pour mission le développement, la promotion et le rayonnement régional, national et international de la musique, en étant au service des œu...vres, des artistes et des organismes musicaux tout en favorisant la diffusion, la production, l’éducation, l’animation et la création. See Morevres, des artistes et des organismes musicaux tout en favorisant la diffusion, la production, l’éducation, l’animation et la création.
company overview: Le Palais Montcalm – Maison de la musique est une corporation constituée en vertu de la partie III de la Loi sur les compagnies du Québec. Organisme à but non l...ucratif, la corporation a pour objet d’exploiter et d’administrer un centre culturel de Québec connu sous le nom de Palais Montcalm comprenant des salles de spectacles principalement vouées au domaine des arts de la scène, ainsi que de promouvoir et favoriser la culture et les échanges culturels.  La programmation du Palais Montcalm est, comme le veut le concept de maison de la musique, tournée vers la découverte musicale. Toutes les musiques y trouvent leur place : le classique, bien sûr, mais aussi les musiques du monde, le jazz, le blues, le folk, le rock progressif, la musique indie et plus encore.  On y présente non seulement des concerts, mais aussi des colloques et conférences, des formations (cours de maître), des ateliers, des visites et concerts commentés, tout cela à saveur musicale et dans le but d’enrichir l’expérience musicale proposée au public. See Moreucratif, la corporation a pour objet d’exploiter et d’administrer un centre culturel de Québec connu sous le nom de Palais Montcalm comprenant des salles de spectacles principalement vouées au domaine des arts de la scène, ainsi que de promouvoir et favoriser la culture et les échanges culturels.  La programmation du Palais Montcalm est, comme le veut le concept de maison de la musique, tournée vers la découverte musicale. Toutes les musiques y trouvent leur place : le classique, bien sûr, mais aussi les musiques du monde, le jazz, le blues, le folk, le rock progressif, la musique indie et plus encore.  On y présente non seulement des concerts, mais aussi des colloques et conférences, des formations (cours de maître), des ateliers, des visites et concerts commentés, tout cela à saveur musicale et dans le but d’enrichir l’expérience musicale proposée au public.
column44: Le Palais Montcalm offre une variété inégalée de styles musicaux. Situé à la place D’Youville, le Palais Montcalm est doté d’une salle de concert de calibre int...ernational, la salle Raoul-Jobin, comptant parmi les meilleures au monde grâce à son acoustique exceptionnelle reconnue et appréciée autant par le public que les interprètes. Le Palais Montcalm comprend également la salle d’Youville, qui offre une ambiance feutrée et chaleureuse.   Le Palais Montcalm est la maison de toutes les musiques! about: Place des Arts is a non-profit arts center and music school located in Maillardville, Coquitlam. www.placedesarts.ca
general information: Recognizable by its striking mansard rooflines, Place des Arts began as a non-profit society in 1972 in Ryan House, a turn-of-the-century residence built for the manager of a lumber mill. In 1996, this community arts centre and music school expanded into 18,000 square feet.
public transit: Transit users can get to Place des Arts by taking bus 153 or 156 from Braid Skytrain station or bus 157 from Lougheed Town Centre.  Drivers can use exit 40B on Highway #1 then proceed east on Brunette Avenue. See map for location overview.
mission: Place des Arts inspires the artist in everyone through our superior learning programs and cultural experiences, our talented people, and our warm, welcoming environment.
products: Arts education for all ages and abilities! Music, dance, theatre arts, visual arts and creative writing!
awards: 2011 Non Profit of the Year - Tri-Cities Chamber of Commerce Business Excellence Awards
column44: Place des Arts is an established arts centre and music school in Coquitlam offering high quality arts education for all ages and abilities from preschool to adu...lt. Whether you are looking for private or group music lessons, dance classes, visual arts classes, theatre arts classes or creative writing classes, Place des Arts has a program for you.  Our Artisan Shop and galleries support local emerging artists, and our events and performances make us a cultural hub, drawing diverse members of the community together to experience the arts. See Morelt. Whether you are looking for private or group music lessons, dance classes, visual arts classes, theatre arts classes or creative writing classes, Place des Arts has a program for you.  Our Artisan Shop and galleries support local emerging artists, and our events and performances make us a cultural hub, drawing diverse members of the community together to experience the arts.

Act Name: PEC FEST 2- "The County's Rock & Blues Fest"
about: "The County's Rock & Blues Fest" has moved to Crystal Palace in Picton, ON. Grab your family and friends and celebrate Summer Solstice with us.
products: music
column44: PEC FEST 2018- "Classic Rock & Smokin' Blues in The County" August 10th and 11th, 2018 Milford Fair Grounds, Milford, Ontario... (2.5 hours from Toronto, 3.5 hours from Ottawa, 4.5 hours from Montreal, 1.25 hours from Kingston)  PEC FEST is a new, music festival starting in beautiful and world-renowned Prince Edward County, Ontario. Truly one of the world's top tourist destinations today. This weekend will be filled with the sounds of classic and blues rock, mostly from Ontario, but with guests from all over Canada. We provide a safe, family-friendly atmosphere that stresses on passing the torch of music to the next generations, which is why we offer a "Kids 12 & Under FREE" policy.  Along with a wonderful roster of music, the weekend will also include several food and craft vendors, special performances, fundraising efforts and more things to be announced.  We will be launching official promotions and ticket sales on December 1st, so stay tuned. Prince Edward County residents will be offered a spectacular deal to show how much we want this festival to be for them, as well as for the visitors to our lovely region.  On-site camping for tents will be offered, with a limited supply of RV spots as well. We will be working EXTREMELY HARD to make this event something that brings a smile to everyone's face. Oh yeah.... and get to know Shelldon The Turtle.... That's Shelldon with TWO L's..... He's the official festival mascot and will be helping to bring awareness to our never-ending fight to watch for turtles in The County.  We are also thrilled to announce that every paid ticket will come with a "PEC FEST poker chip".... You get to choose between 3 charities.... So get ready to "throw in your chip". Each chip gets the charity a donation. about: Salle de spectacle intime dans un décor chic et urbain. Le Petit Théâtre de Québec diffuse des pièces de théâtre, des spectacles de chanson, de musique et des conférences.
company overview: Organisme à but non-lucratif
products: Billets de spectacle / location de salle
column44: Le Petit Théâtre de Québec situé en plein cœur du centre-ville de Québec est un complexe culturel de 3 étages . Au rez-de-chaussée, une salle de spectacle intim...e complètement équipée, pouvant accueillir 83 spectateurs ainsi qu'un Café-Bar, une grande loge. Aux étages supérieurs, des locaux de répétition,  un espace de co-working "L'EspaceCo.  La salle convient parfaitement aux compagnies théâtrales, aux petits ensembles musicaux, aux conférenciers, aux spectacles d’humour aux tournages et on peut même y projeter des films. Tous les avantages d’un grand théâtre dans un Petit Théâtre!  Principaux avantages :  •	Salle calibrée par un ingénieur de son; •	Service de technicien régie son-éclairage; •	Loges spacieuses pouvant accueillir 12 personnes; •	Salle d’habillage à même la loge; •	Entrée des artistes et stationnement (11 voitures); •	Grande salle de répétition; •	Coulisses jardin-cour avec passage communicant en arrière scène; •	Cyclorama blanc pour projection 16 :9; •	Rideau noir en fond de scène pouvant cacher le cyclorama; •	Projecteur multimédia haute définition; •	Régie entièrement équipée et isolée du public, filée pour captations vidéo; •	Espace spectateur en gradins offrant une excellente visibilité de la scène; •	Système chauffage-climatisation récent offrant un grand confort;  Café-bar  •	Machine espresso Simonelli commerciale; •	Décors actuel avec une touche rétro; •	Permis de bar vin-bière; •	Service de traiteur sur demande See Moree complètement équipée, pouvant accueillir 83 spectateurs ainsi qu'un Café-Bar, une grande loge. biography: PK Tessmann is a fixture in the Vancouver Island indie-folk community. Her well-crafted, original songs are something of substance - a synergy of flowing lyrics..., twinkling ukelele and acoustic guitar, and soul-stirring vocals. With a decade of songwriting and performance behind her, Tessmann is now celebrating the release of her brand new album Dear City.  Two-time winner of Best Roots/Folk Recording at the Vancouver Island Music Awards, Tessmann's work has been described as “beguiling,” “potent, ” and “unpretentious”. Her latest work is no exception. Dear City is a collection of songs that offer a window into Tessmann's journey into marriage and motherhood. With each haunting song, she offers up her experiences of grief, hope, loss and new beginnings. Produced by Corwin Fox (Shane Koyczan, CR Avery, Miss Emily Brown) in the vibrant village of Cumberland BC, Dear City showcases Tessmann's songwriting with colourful yet subtle instrumentation. Vintage keys, bells, autoharp, cello, French horn and saxophone combined with whispered harmonies to compliment Tessmann's spirited vocals. An alumni of the Capilano College Jazz program in Vancouver BC, PK Tessmann has released two previous records, including full-length album Maybe and a self-titled EP. In addition to her two recent VIMA awards, she has garnered further VIMA nominations for Vocalist of the Year, Song of the Year and Video of the Year, and she recently took home the title of Regional Champion in the 2015 CBC Searchlight Contest.  Contact PK Tessmann at : H: (250)336-8474 C: (250)650-6655 Info@pktessmann.ca PO Box 886 Cumberland, BC V0R 1S0  For more information on PK and upcoming shows, please visit these websites:  www.pktessmann.ca www.twitter.com/pktessmann www.facebook.com/pktessmann www.youtube.com/pktessmann See More, twinkling ukelele and acoustic guitar, and soul-stirring vocals. Page Types: Performance Art Theatre | Live Music Venue
about: The Port Theatre is an 800-seat theatre on the breathtaking waterfront in downtown Nanaimo. The purpose of The Port Theatre Society is to stimulate and enhance artistic, cultural and economic activity of central Vancouver Island.
products: Performing Arts, Theatre, Music, Dance
column44: The theatre is a focal point for residents and visitors alike, offering a broad range of cultural events designed to meet many diverse interests and needs. Prog...rams involve local groups as well as touring attractions and provide access to events for families, seniors, youths and adults, thereby enriching the overall quality of life in the region. A landmark on the city's waterfront, it also serves as an important meeting place for a variety of community events, seminars and educational conferences. Over 250 events are held in the theatre each year attracting over 100,000 people.  Architect of The Port Theatre, Terry Williams' goal was to build a theatre that had good sight lines from all seats, excellent acoustics and a wonderful sense of intimacy. Audiences have raved about these features since it opened.  The Port Theatre Society was formed in 1989 to raise money to build an 800-seat theatre on the breathtaking waterfront in downtown Nanaimo.  The Port Theatre opened in September of 1998, thanks to grants from the Federal/Provincial Infrastructure Works Program and an outstanding level of community support. Since then, The Port Theatre has continued to be supported through the creation of a number of initiatives and through the people of this community who selflessly commit their time and effort to lend a hand.  Volunteers truly make The Port Theatre’s world go round. Since its inception, The Port Theatre has relied on volunteers to assist with everything from washing linens to answering phones. On show nights, over 20 volunteers may be present to light the way to your seat, sell you a treat, and take your coat. Their talents, humour, and guidance are always appreciated in areas such as the administration and participation in committees. With over 200 volunteers, The Port Theatre is blessed to have a full complement from which to draw upon for support, advice, and friendship.   Fulfilling this mission requires much public support. The Port Theatre has a number of initiatives which include annual and capital donations, show sponsorship, and memberships. For only $25 a year for a basic membership, show goers can enjoy discounts, advanced buys, and advanced notice to upcoming events. The Port Theatre also offers corporate memberships that offer an opportunity for employers to treat their staff.  The Arts is for everyone. The Port Theatre’s ‘Theatre Angel Program’ provides complimentary tickets to people in the region who would not normally be able to purchase a ticket to a live performance event. The tickets are distributed by various social service agencies and the program has proven to highlight someone’s day and enrich their lives through the arts.   Ticket sales are available online at www.porttheatre.com or by calling the Ticket Centre at 250-754-8550. The Ticket Centre is open Monday to Friday from 11am – 5:30pm and Saturday from 12pm – 5pm. It is also open two hours prior to every show. The Port Theatre strives to offer high quality Canadian content – so be sure to check out the next show!  Please help support the Arts through your donation, membership or by becoming a Theatre Angel – Your Gift will make a difference! column44: Double Concept Productions was founded in Montreal, QC, in 1992, by Nathalie Lavergne.  ​ At the time, the event producer launched the Rockabilly Jam and in 200...5, the Red Hot & Blue Rockabilly Weekend. The company has worked to promote different municipal events such as Le Cabaret du 10e and Nuit Blanche au Musée des Beaux Arts, both created for the Montreal High Lights Festival.  ​ The 100th anniversary of the Grey Cup, held across the country in 2013 hired Double Concept to take care of Quebec City and Montreal stops, working closely with Via Rail, Montreal Old Port, Quebec Gare du Palais train station and the Montreal Alouettes.  ​ Passionate about events, Nathalie has surrounded herself over the years with a team of professional Sound and Lighting Technicians, DJs, bands, Photographers, Chefs, Catering professionals, etc.  ​ Beginning in January 2016, Nathalie and her spouse Amund Christensen mixed their passion with business by opening the Spitfire Café in the heart of Brockville. about: Rhizome est un générateur de projets interdisciplinaires dont le cœur est littéraire.   Pour nous joindre : productionsrhizome.org/fr/apropos/117/equipe
mission: Qu'est-ce que Rhizome?  Sa démarche, basée sur la recherche et l’innovation, ne perd jamais de vue l’objet littéraire. Le texte, ainsi que son auteur•e, en sont... les fondements. Rhizome initie, accompagne, crée, produit, coproduit, accueille en résidence des projets dans lesquels des auteur•e•s s’impliquent, tant dans le processus de création que lors des représentations. Les formes sont diverses – performances, installations, spectacles – et profitent fréquemment des possibilités qu’ouvrent les technologies numériques. À travers ses productions, Rhizome cherche différents moyens de faire participer la littérature, en tant que discipline artistique, à une démarche interdisciplinaire de création. Le but est de favoriser son décloisonnement et, ce faisant, d’apporter à la pratique interdisciplinaire sa richesse sémantique.  Depuis sa fondation à Québec en 2000, Rhizome a produit plus d’une soixantaine de spectacles qui ont été diffusés au Québec, au Canada, aux États-Unis, au Mexique, en Argentine, en France, en Belgique et en Haïti.  Rhizome remercie les auteur•e•s, les artistes, les organismes et tous les partenaires qui contribuent à la réalisation des différents projets. See More les fondements. awards: En 2006, Rhizome remporte le 1er prix du concours Graphika dans la catégorie Affiche culturelle, finaliste pour le Prix d’excellence du Conseil de la Culture de...s régions de Québec et Chaudière-Appalaches dans la catégorie Rayonnement international offert par le CALQ et finaliste pour le prix de l’Office Québec-Wallonie-Bruxelles pour la Jeunesse dans la catégorie Meilleur stage réalisé en Wallonie-Bruxelles. column44: Home of the Kelowna Rockets Hockey Club, Prospera Place is a state of the art sports and entertainment facility open year-round in the heart of downtown Kelowna.... Since it's beginnings as Skyreach Place, the building has hosted hundreds of concerts, tradeshows and sporting events from small-scale sports teams to the 2006 World Juniors. Come enjoy a big arena feel with luxury suites, fine dining and great entertainment in a more affordable and intimate setting with one single tier of seats. With 6,000 available seats during Rockets games and varying capacity for shows, no seat is a bad seat. Be sure to check out Select Your Tickets for all upcoming shows at Prospera Place. See More. company overview: À 30 km de Sherbrooke, dans l’ancien magasin général de Saint-Camille, le P'tit Bonheur est un organisme de développement culturel et communautaire qui vous off...re une salle de spectacle intimiste de 110 places, sa légendaire pizza du vendredi, son excellent café espresso ou l'exposition du moment. products: Spectacles dans une salle intimiste, pizzas maison tous les vendredis, lieu d'exposition (espace Hortense), café, Internet sans fil et ordinateurs,  location de salles, location d'espaces de travail...
awards: Le P'tit Bonheur est au coeur d'une riche dynamique locale à Saint-Camille. Présenté comme « village-monde » par Le Monde diplomatique en 2006, la détermination..., la créativité et la solidarité dont sa population fait preuve pour relever les défis propres à la ruralité sont aujourd'hui reconnues comme un modèle de développement. En plus de ces activités culturelles, le P’tit bonheur pilote la stratégie Inode Estrie (www.inodeestrie.qc.ca), le Laboratoire rural de Saint-Camille et le portail Mes Sources (www.messources.org). Les activités du village ont récemment fait l’objet du film « Ne touchez pas à mon église ! » (Bruno Boulianne, 2012), du film « Les irréductibles » (Isaac Isitan, 2011) et du livre « Saint-Camille, le pari de la convivialité » (Jocelyne Béïque, Écosociété, 2011). See More, la créativité et la solidarité dont sa population fait preuve pour relever les défis propres à la ruralité sont aujourd'hui reconnues comme un modèle de développement. En plus de ces activités culturelles, le P’tit bonheur pilote la stratégie Inode Estrie (www.inodeestrie.qc.ca), le Laboratoire rural de Saint-Camille et le portail Mes Sources (www.messources.org). Les activités du village ont récemment fait l’objet du film « Ne touchez pas à mon église ! » (Bruno Boulianne, 2012), du film « Les irréductibles » (Isaac Isitan, 2011) et du livre « Saint-Camille, le pari de la convivialité » (Jocelyne Béïque, Écosociété, 2011).
