about: The Astor Theatre serves the community by providing a venue for live theatre, music, lectures, movies, private functions, festivals and community gatherings.
column44: The Astor Theatre is proud to be the oldest performing arts venue in the province. In 2002 the Astor Theatre celebrated 100 years of entertainment on the South ...Shore of Nova Scotia.  Built in 1902 as part of the historic Town Hall, the theatre was known as the Liverpool Opera House. It's stage hosted touring and local shows until 1917, when silent films were introduced. Gradually the film presentation gained in frequency and popularity. In 1930, talking pictures were shown for the first time. The first "talkie" shown in the theatre was "Love in the Rough", a comedy on golf. at the same time the name was changed to the Astor Theatre by Seth Bartling Sr. after his favourite theatre in New York.   During World War II the cinema featured regular war documentaries; news reels about the War in Europe became a staple of the Astor's presentations. Shortly after the war the theatre was renovated to accommodate more people in the balcony as cinema presentations grew in popularity. A new screen format was installed to allow cinemascope pictures in the late 50's. A larger screen was installed and the proscenium arch was widened to allow for the larger pictures. As well, the tin ceiling was plastered over to compensate for amplified sound.   For a time, there were few live presentations. In 1979, with increased interest in live presentation, the Astor began presenting local talent through the Winds of Change Dramatic Society. With the installation of a new thrust stage, the stage area was increased to accommodate larger and larger performing acts. In June 1987 The Astor Theatre Society was incorporated as a non-profit, charitable organization.   The Astor has played host to many touring artists including Matt Andersen, George Canyon, Barra MacNeils, Jill Barber, Rufus Wainright, Stewart MacLean, Ron James, Rita MacNeil, Natalie MacMaster, Tommy Hunter, Carroll Baker, George Fox, Mr. Dressup, Symphony Nova Scotia, Debut Atlantic and the Royal Shakespeare Company to name a few. A particularly interesting feature is the tin ceiling. The entire theatre used to have a similar ceiling, but changes were made to enhance the sound quality as it's usage changed. However, the change in the main ceiling did not affect the acoustics which are some of the best in the province. Numerous artists have commented on this confirming they are "the best around". The high rounded ceilings and the plaster walls make the Astor a wonderful place to enjoy concerts and plays. Why not find out for yourself? See MoreShore of Nova Scotia. about: IG: @olympiamontreal L'Olympia,théâtre centenaire, présente des spectacles d'envergure et peut acceuillir jusqu'à 2400 personnes.
public transit: Métro Berri-UQAM ou Métro Beaudry
products: Spectacles
column44: IG: @olympiamontreal Snapchat: OlympiaMontreal ... Bâti en 1925, l’Olympia de Montréal est l’un des joyaux les plus précieux des milieux culturels et architecturaux montréalais. Ses longues années consacrées au "théâtre cinématographique" lui ont conféré un cachet tout particulier. Il y flotte un air du passé doublé d’une ambiance conviviale inégalée. Sa situation géographique privilégiée (Métro Berri-UQAM) en fait l’un des théâtres les plus facilement accessibles à Montréal.  Ses murs résonnent encore des voix des plus grands noms de la scène musicale québécoise et internationale ; de Gilles Vigneault à Tori Amos, en passant par Daniel Bélanger, Claude Léveillé, Georges Brassens, Loreena McKennitt et les Rita Mitsouko. Outre sa vocation musicale, l’Olympia de Montréal a su agrandir ses horizons culturels en accueillant les plus grands comiques québécois (Louis-José Houde, Daniel Lemire, Clémence Desrochers, Lise Dion, Jean-Michel Anctil) ainsi que plusieurs oeuvres théâtrales. Broue, symbole du théâtre québécois, y a d’ailleurs tenu l’affiche pendant plus de dix-sept ans. C’est également le lieu parfait pour tous types d’événements corporatifs, tels que les réunions d’entreprises, les conférences en tous genres et les événements bénéfices.  Récemment repris par une nouvelle administration soucieuse de sauvegarder une salle unique en son genre, à l’acoustique hors du commun et à un son qualité numérique, l’Olympia de Montréal offre des services divers pour tous types d’événements. Récemment repris par une nouvelle administration soucieuse de sauvegarder une salle unique en son genre, à l’acoustique hors du commun et à un son qualité numérique, l’Olympia de Montréal offre des services divers pour tous types d’événements.

about: Le Patriote de Ste-Agathe,salle mythique de la scène culturelle québécoise, offre des spectacles depuis 53 ans. Billetterie: 819 326-3655, 1 888 326-3655.
column44: Depuis 1967, le théâtre Le Patriote est un chef de file dans la présentation de spectacles des plus grands de la chanson, de l'humour et du théâtre. C'est un li...eu mythique de la vie culturelle québécoise qui vu défiler au fil des années une quantité impressionnante de chanteurs, de musiciens, d'humoristes et d'acteurs. Dans un décor champêtre, près du majestueux Lac des Sables, le théâtre Le Patriote convie le spectateur à une expérience unique où la proximité entre le public et l'artiste, la chaleur et l'histoire des lieux contribuent à créer des moments magiques. Il fait partie de l'histoire de la chanson québécoise tout comme il fait partie du patrimoine de Sainte-Agathe-des-Monts et fait l'orgueil des Agathois. Du lancement d’un album à la présentation d’un spectacle sur scène (en mode production, diffusion ou location), en passant par des causeries après-spectacles, tables rondes, classes de maîtres et autres activités de sensibilisation, un artiste peut trouver en nos murs toutes les ressources pour paver les avenues le conduisant à son public. L’intégration des diverses fonctions que nous assumons fait de nous un allié précieux pour le développement de démarches artistiques de la relève et des professionnels du milieu. about: Community Theatre in Leamington where everyone can enjoy the performing Arts!
mission: The Bank Theatre is a live performance venue for the performing arts. Our Mandate - To provide quality live theatre, dance and musical performances and a training ground for students in our diverse community.
column44: The Bank Theatre is located at 10 Erie Street south in uptown Leamington Ontario. The building was constructed circa 1850 and prior to ownership by the Sun Parl...our Players Community Theatre, it was a Bank of Montreal, hence the name The Bank Theatre.  Phase I of the renovations was completed in late August 2012. Phase II of the renovation plan included raising the roof to accommodate an additional 100 seats in state of the art tiered seating and many other structural improvements. Funding for Phase II was provided by the Community Infrastructure Improvement Fund and the Municipality of Leamington.  The theatre opened it’s doors to the public on August 31, 2012, with a production of Calendar Girls. The quaint 100 seat venue sold out all shows building confidence to all those invested that in completion the main floor with tiered seating for 212 guests would be able to accommodate the interest of our vibrant community. Sun Parlour Players Community Theatre, in its present state, was formed in 1973, but its history goes back to the early 1950’s. Since their inception, SPPCT have run workshops and staged over 100 comedies, musicals, dramas and children’s productions, of which many were written by Canadian authors.  The Bank Theatre is a labour of love for many hard working volunteers, a dedicated Board of Directors, committees, and members, and we continue to partner with various organizations in Leamington and throughout Essex County.  The passion for top notch live performances, arts and culture events and the drive to revitalize the Municipality of Leamington’s uptown core is shared by the Municipality of Leamington, private, corporate and government funders. Once all interior and exterior improvements are completed, The Bank Theatre will become a vibrant, viable, state of the art facility that is accessible and WIFI ready. column44: WHO WE ARE  The Birds Nest has evolved into a fantastic, international music and arts venue while retaining its original South London flavour. Located at the en...d of Creekside and on the borders of Greenwich and Deptford, the pub is a hub of artists and musicians. Live music varies from folk to hardcore punk, Blues to Ska, established well known bands, to up-and-coming local talent, The Birds Nest always has quality live music.  You will also find a wide choice of delicious meat, fish and vegan burgers at affordable prices and served throughout the day as well as traditional Sunday Roast’s with the option of meat, vegan or vegetarian.  Formerly The Oxford Arms the pub has hosted such big names as Squeeze and Dire Straits and continues today to bring top bands to Deptford. Further back in the 16th century, the pub was a centre for arts. Deptford Theatre was joined to the pub, the playwright, Christopher Marlowe was connected to this theatre.  WHAT'S ON  Presently the pub has live original music and performances on Fridays & Saturdays with occasional Sundays.  A popular feature of the pub is its happy hour. Monday to Friday 5pm to 7pm, when all pints are only £3.50 each.  **Please Note**  Most of the gigs here are put together by outside promoters so please contact them if you wish to play, not us. about: The Brockville Arts Centre
column44: Leading Canadian artists and performers have touted the Brockville Arts Centre as Canada’s foremost midsized historic theatre.  The recent $2 million facelift, ...has raised the eyebrows of Canada’s musical elite with a sound system equivalent to Celine Dion’s Las Vegas system. Luxurious seating duplicated form Washington’s Lincoln Centre and historic chandeliers from the Trump Plaza in Atlantic City.  One of the most memorable compliments comes from renowned Canadian Artist, John McDermott, who was quoted that “of the many continents he has performed at, Brockville Arts Centre has acoustic excellence second to none”.  Other artists who have recently performed at the Brockville Arts Centre include; Harry Connick Jr., Tragically Hip, Great Big Sea, Michelle Wright and several touring groups. The historic Brockville Arts Centre will continue to be a significant attraction with the recruitment of creative talent seeking a home for performance where resort living is an everyday occurrence. For more information on the Brockville Arts Centre and its programming visit: http://www.brockvilleartscentre.com/ See Morehas raised the eyebrows of Canada’s musical elite with a sound system equivalent to Celine Dion’s Las Vegas system. about: The Buckingham AKA The Buck, Whyte Ave's most eclectic alternative nightspot. Music, live shows and all things ridiculous since June 2013.
column44: An alternative pub in the heart of bustling Whyte Avenue, The Buckingham is perfectly suited for those discontented with the standard bar scene. Since we are bu...ilt on community values such as inclusion and anti-pretention, anybody with a good attitude will find this a desirable location (Except for Gidian who borrowed my GameBoy Colour in grade 4, then his family moved to Pittsburg and he never gave it back. You did that on purpose Gidian, you're banned, who's laughing now huh?!")  Our kitchen is proud to be serving up a pub-fare themed menu that is all vegan, brought to you by our long haired bro-snakes from The Sailin' On Food Truck.  Tight jams, no harsh tokes.  We are actively involved in Edmonton's music scene, and with that you can expect an atmosphere which reflects that. Be it through quality live shows, karaoke nights, or just a bustling weekend on the dance floor, we offer a bunch of stuff to entertain your lazy butts.   "Actual" customer testimonials!:  "That bar is really fun." -Simple Jon from Edson  "I love The Buckingham and I will gladly put my personal endorsement behind it!" -Bill Murray (...a different Bill Murray, this guy has an afro and works as a barista at Second Cup)  "I'm not lending you any more money, stop calling me at work." -My Uncle Davey  "Who are you and how did you get in my living room?" -??? column44: Casual Canadian cuisine in the heart of downtown Halifax, Nova Scotia.  The Carleton is also one of Canada's premiere 'listening rooms' and has featured a who's...-who of the Canadian (and international) music scene.   The daring (darling/bold/goofy/cuckoo) venture of MuchMusic pioneers Mike Campbell & Mike Rhodes (Mike & Mike's Excellent X-Canada Adventures, MuchEast, Going Coastal), the Carleton has proven to be a huge success, claiming Music Nova Scotia's "Venue of the Year" four times (2009, 2010, 2011, 2012) and the current holder of the same award from the East Coast Music Association (ECMA).   A favourite watering hole for locals, and a must-visit for music fans (as well as anyone who likes good food and swell drinks in an adult environment). The Carleton Music Bar & Grill just might be your Haligonian hangout but you'll have to visit to see for yourself... See More-who of the Canadian (and international) music scene. column44: Located on the main street of Parry Sound just up from the waterfront, The Charles W. Stockey Center/Festival of the Sound,  Island Queen boat cruise and Georgi...an Bay Airways tours. Open  year round and serve all day breakfast & lunch!  All of our food is made in house with fresh healthy ingredients.  We have comfort food like lasagna, shepherd's Pie, perogies, meatloaf, steakmelts, macaroni and cheese, but also love our curries & spices and tend to have many different spicy items in our soups, salads & specials. Fresh ground coffee, lattes, wide variety of cold drinks (diet, organic, artisan) two glass cases full of home made desserts and squares. Act Name: Sharbot Lake Inn & The Crossing Pub
about: Welcome to the Sharbot Lake Country Inn & Crossing Pub. Located in the heart of the Land of a Thousand Lakes come join us for food, music and fun.
column44: The Sharbot Lake Country Inn & The Crossing Pub, as it is known today, has had a long and varied history. The original structure was built in 1906 by Dr. H. Cou...tlee,who graduated from Queens University in 1882 as a Doctor of Medicine and Master of Surgery. Dr. Coutlee’s plans were to establish his first medical office in Sharbot Lake and open a medical center and clinic with a few beds for short stays. Unfortunately, due to his untimely death, his plan never materialized and he left the building to Dan and Diana Buchanan, his manager and  housekeeper. The Buchanan’s later decided to convert the building into a bed and breakfast, and named it The Hillcrest Inn.  After Danny Buchanan’s death in 1952, Mrs. Buchanan sold the Inn to a gentleman from Perth, Ontario. Over the years, the Inn has had several name changes and a variety of owners. Today, even after all the name changes, renovations, and additions, the original building still remains more or less as it was when it was originally built. Now known as the Sharbot Lake Country Inn & The Crossing Pub, current owners Frankand Sandra White strive to protect its history.  The pub’s name, The Crossing, is both a reference to Sharbot Lake’s history as a railroad town, as well as recognition of the towns Stephenville and Stephenville Crossing in Newfoundland where Frankand Sandra White were born and raised.   In addition to the Sharbot Lake Country Inn & The Crossing Pub, the Inn also provides services such as massage therapy and chiropractic care.  We hope you enjoy your stay with us. Act Name: The Embassy, Live Music Cafe Kingston
Page Types: Cafe | Nonprofit Organization | Live Music Venue
about: The Embassy Live Music Cafe, is an initiative of local charity Lionhearts inc. The Embassy strives to provide the best live music experience with Coffee.
general information: 129 Wellington St. "The Great Hall" entrance of St. Georges Cathedral. The Embassy Live Music Cafe is a pop up cafe that happens every Saturday evening year round. Kingstons only dry live music venue.
mission: to create the best possible live music venue with a priority of allowing access and friendship to the poor
company overview: The Embassy Live Music Cafe was started by Lionhearts inc. in January of 2017. By partnering with St. Georges Cathedral Kingston, Its mission is provide the bes...t live music experience for all who attend. What sets The Embassy apart for the rest is that it has a specific charity d.n.a. which would be to hand out free entry tickets weekly to those that are on the street, and or marginalized. The ticket they receive looks the same as a purchased entry ticket ($5), therefore there is no distinction between guests. This ticket can be redeemed at inside at our cafe counter, for 1 hot or cold beverage of choice, as well as a delicious pastry, savoury slice of pizza, or jumbo hot dog.   It is our priority that marginalized receive the same friendship and dignity as everyone else. If anything we strive to go above and beyond for those that need the extra love / friendship / dignity. Music can be a therapy, so can a hot cup of coffee and friendly face on a cold day. We feel that providing the best music venue atmosphere with the best sound and excellent music, and including the marginalized will uplift there spirits and give hope for a brighter future. about: Extinguish Your Thirst with the Beer of Wine Country!
products: Draught Beer Local Wine/Cider/Spirits Limited Food Menu
column44: BEER SHOP & SOCIAL  Open Noon 'til Night Everyday Courageously Crowdfunded 2016...  Fires have long left their legacy in the arid South Okanagan, claiming many historic buildings such as the “Big Teepee” Hotel in the old Fairview mining town. When the mines ran out of gold, the residents moved down to the young village of Oliver, where a newly built irrigation ditch brought different riches to the parched landscape: agriculture. The town of Oliver still stands, but the fire station siren is often heard screaming across town in the desert air.  In recent times, the volunteer firefighters built a modern fire station, leaving the original “Old Firehall” downtown in the heart of Canada’s Wine Capital. It is now the home of our brewery, where we pump out thirst-extinguishing ales with courageous flavour and alarming drinkability. Our passion for real craft beer is only rivalled by our love for music and the great outdoors.  Welcome to the Craft Beer Revolution! column44: The Knndy has the comfortable feel of a pub with the entertainment and vibe of a nightclub. Live music and the hottest DJ's are featured.  The Knndy is an intim...ate venue nestled in Winnipeg's upcoming downtown area. It's true that it's a block or two off the beaten path, but our selection of draught beer, cocktails and entertainment make it worth the trip.  Formerly known as the Lo Pub, we chose to carry on the tradition of live music.  We upgraded the entire PA and light show and now regularly host Winnipeg's hottest Indie, Punk, Rock, Metal, Folk, Pop and Americana acts.  We have also taken on our own identity as the place for electronic music.  The sound and the light show on the dancefloor is second to none at a Winnipeg Pub of our size and we feature all different kinds of electronic music throughout the week.  If you want to get involved, or host your next event at the Knndy, please feel free to contact us today. Page Types: Performance & Event Venue | Church | Religious Organization
about: The Lantern: A Christian community on a journey together, a music & art school, a beautiful venue for weddings and concerts.. and so much more!
mission: We invite people into an accepting, relevant, creative community.
column44: The Lantern Community Church in Inglewood is a beautiful historic building built in 1912. Original woodwork and stained glass give it a warmth and ambiance that... is rarely found.  It has become a favorite place for weddings.  A vibrant congregation has it's home here; reaching the community and growing together in the Christian faith are founding principals of this Christian Reformed Church.   The Inglewood Arts and Music School is run out of the church and has has more than 800 students over the years - offering inexpensive choir, vocal, piano, guitar, Spanish language lessons and art classes.  The building is the home to The Inglewood Music Club and has been host to the likes of Martyn Joseph, Eric Bibb, Jacob Moon, Marc Cohn, Don Ross, The Cowtown Opera  and many, many more.   Live theatre like Fire Exit Theatre are regulars at The Lantern. We are proud to partner with The Fringe Fest and Bleak Mid Winter Fillm Fest!  This Facebook page endeavors to be a place to to tie all these areas together and promote community and relationship  SUNDAY SERVICES: 10AM See our Website Calendar for Events times and descriptions! Providing you live music, great food and drinks in the heart of Commercial Drive
column44: We're under new management! Stay tuned for an updated menu.  Welcome to the Libra Room, the only spot in Vancouver to catch live music seven-nights-a-week. Now ...in its tenth year of transformation, the Libra Room – located in the heart of Commercial Drive – has carved out its own unique niche in the community.  Like the neighbourhood it’s situated in, the space is colourfully eclectic. Wooden tables, chairs, centre-bar and performance stage add a rustic charm to the perennial haunt. Works from local artists decorate the walls. Each month a new artist is featured with the pieces available for purchase.  The Libra Room is home to young burgeoning musicians and Vancouver jazz giants such as John Korsrud, Wes Mackey and Bruno Hubert. Two bands perform nightly, taking the stage at 6:30 pm and 9 pm respectively. Supporting the local music scene, the Libra Room has played host to major musical events, such as the New Music West festival, The Juno Festival and the Vancouver Jazz Festival. about: The Grand has become known to local patrons as the place that has "something for everyone"!  **Rated Best Pub by Readers Choice 2019!!** **VOTED BEST WING in LINDSAY 2020!!**
products: In House Dining, Pub Style Bar, Take-Out & Delivery, Off-Site Catering & In House Parties!
column44: The Grand Experience has been a Lindsay staple for decades. Encompassing half a city block, it's become known to local patrons as the place that has 'something ...for everyone'.   Originally known has the Market Hotel, the building occupied a position of importance in Lindsay’s shopping area in the late 1800’s. The Queens Square was where farmers would display their wares each and every week, with The Grand being a spot for the  travelling merchants and their horses to stay while they were in the Lindsay area.  Fast forward to the early 1980’s, when The Grand Experience restaurant was added to the The Grand building, giving Lindsay a popular dining spot to go along with the well known Grand Pub.   As of today, The Grand is owned and operated by Charlie McDonald since 2010. Since Charlie's arrival, The Grand Experience has seen several renovations to better accommodate his customers, so if you haven’t been to The Grand lately, you should take an evening, stop by for dinner and check out The Grand Experience! about: Filling the empty space Don't want to miss anything? Go to LIKE icon & check "Get Notifications" & "Show in News Feed."
mission: MT Space is dedicated to theatre that centralizes marginalized voices to address social issues and constitute a vibrant intercultural community.  GUIDING PRINCI...PLES/VALUES: -Community -Collaboration -Risk-taking -Social responsibility -Accessibility -Solidarity  VISION: Just theatre.  A community of difference. See MorePLES/VALUES: -Community -Collaboration -Risk-taking -Social responsibility -Accessibility -Solidarity  VISION: Just theatre.  A community of difference.
company overview: MT Space supports seven distinct yet overlapping streams of activity:  Creating, Producing and Touring New Canadian Work - MT Space develops new theatre product...ions through our process of research and creation workshops. One of our milestone pieces is The Last 15 Seconds which premiered in 2009 at our inaugural IMPACT Festival and went on to tour across Canada and to the Middle East where it received rave reviews. Most recently, MT Space co-produced Paradise with Gwaandak Theatre from Whitehorse, which has been performed for audiences in Kitchener and the Yukon and is being prepared for touring in 2017/2018 and beyond.  IMPACT Festival - Launched in 2009, the International Multicultural Platform for Alternative Contemporary Theatre (IMPACT) is a biennial international theatre festival and industry conference. In 2015, over 6 days, IMPACT 15 hosted 15 companies from Canada, Morocco, and Australia, performing in 37 shows for over 4000 audience members, in addition to a national industry conference and the first ever Stage & Story Market, a free family-friendly outdoor event. The IMPACT 17 festival for the first time included a Theatre for Young Audiences component which involved several mainstage shows as well as a Family Pavilion at the historic Schneider Haus and a Youth Conference.  Presenting Series - This series enables us to offer high quality, diverse and affordable theatre programming year round, something that no one else is currently doing in our region. In the past three years, MT Space has developed into a recognizable presenter of unconventional and independent work that comes from marginalized and racialized communities and continues to develop into one of the most highly respected and sought after presenters of Indigenous and culturally diverse theatre in Canada.  Theatre for Social Change - MT Space works with schools and community organizations to create theatre productions which explore researched cultural, health and social issues within our community. Topics have included addictions, global issues, youth and volunteerism, hate crimes, mental health and stigma, immigration and displacement, and faith.  Newcomer Youth Project / Young Company - Over the past eight years, the MT Space (in partnership with YMCA Immigrant Services) has worked with over 300 immigrant and refugee youth from five high schools in Kitchener, Waterloo and Cambridge, to gain confidence and build community through the Newcomer Youth Theatre Project. This program feeds directly into the MT Space Young Company, a more in-depth theatre training program which allows students to further develop their skills as theatre artists while receiving mentorship from a local cultural community leader.  Workshops and Education - MT Space brings theatre professionals from across the globe to provide high-level professional training for members of the community. In 2015 we presented a week-long Butoh dance workshop with Natsu Nakajima, a Master of the style. Mostly recently, MT Space hosted renowned Tunisian theatre director, Fadhel Jaibi, who gave a two week advanced workshop in devised theatre.  Incubation - By providing mentorship and access to space and other resources, we have created an environment in which artists and organizations in the community are able to grow and develop; including Kitchener-Waterloo Arab-Canadian Theatre, the Kaleidoscope Collective, and Theatre Mada. about: Located in Pembroke, Ontario. The Nelson Street Pub is your place to go for intoxicating drinks, ridiculously good food, and unrivaled entertainment (and maybe a few shenanigans).
column44: The Nelson Street Pub has been a vision created by you.   "There's nothing to do in this town." is a phrase we've heard way too often. So we decided to do somet...hing about it. And it was quite simple when we sat down to think about it, let's give everyone exactly what they want, and have been asking for.  A place to go after work and have a pint with their buddies.  Somewhere to go and listen to great live music.  A place to go with your girls on a Friday night.  Somewhere you can grab a drink, and a bite to eat before you go back home and deal with that mother-in-law.  Familiar faces, where everybody knows your name. (And they're always glad you came.)  We have created a great atmosphere where you can simply go and hang out and have a great time. Simple as that, and its how we're going to keep it.  Ridiculously good food. Intoxicating drinks. Great entertainment.  From us, to you. See Morehing about it. And it was quite simple when we sat down to think about it, let's give everyone exactly what they want, and have been asking for. about: We make space for change makers and movement builders. Grow at your own Pace.
impressum: Accessibility Information  Variety of seating: office chairs, sofas, bean bags. Differing heights, some with arms, some without. Sizes to fit all body types....  Variety of sizes and heights of tables and desks. Includes tables/desks accessible for people with mobility aids.  Ability to mix seating and tables/desks to create personal seating plans.  Level, stable, firm, concrete flooring, accessible to mobility devices.  1st floor is not accessible through the front door because of stairs but there is a ramp with an 8% grade accessible through the garage door.  2nd floor is not accessible to people with mobility aids and/or those unable to climb stairs.  Ability to maneuver a mobility device on both levels of the building. (This can be affected by how individual hosts set up the seating.)  Two all gender washrooms on the first floor. The largest door width is 750mm. Neither washroom is currently accessible to people with mobility aids but work is being done to make one more accessible.   Lighting is fluorescent.  Building is made of concrete which can affect the sound. The second floor has less bouncing of sound.  Guide and service dogs are welcome.  Handrails for stairs on all main routes.  Ability to have quiet space or low stimulation space upstairs.  Please ask about any accessibility needs and/or concerns, our staff have made a conscious effort to be aware of accessibility facilitators and barriers within our venue.  ATM available with operating headphone jack and voice commands for people who are partially sighted or blind.  Free wifi. See More  Variety of sizes and heights of tables and desks. column44: "Pulp Paper and People" by Karen Southern and Peggy Bird 1988 The Patricia Theatre - by Karen Southern... Remember the exciting silents? The actors rushing about in jerky movements while the train bore down on the maiden tied to the track and the pianist played his best train-bearing-down music. And of course, the villain with his waxed mustache exclaiming,in sub-titles, “Curses, foiled again!” Powell River had its own silent theatre (located at the present cenotaph) where Stan Meade tinkled the ivories, and Bobby Scanlon opened the side door to the children without dimes. He was a well loved manager who controlled the rambunctious teenagers with kindness, and winked at the lovers who sat beneath the balcony. Young Frank Haslam went down after school and flopped back the kitchen chairs to sweep the floor of the old “Pat” theatre. The first four rows of chairs were joined together by a plank underneath, with hinges for easy cleaning. For this service he was allowed to see any show that played, free of charge. He was also part of a pie-eating contest that Bobby held to draw the crowd one night. The spotlight was shone on their blueberry faces as Frank was judged first by Mrs. E.A. Sadler and given the coveted prize, an American silver dollar. Curly Woodward was one of those contestants. It took him a week to get the pie out of his ears. He was a regular customer to the flicks, one who didn’t mind getting his fifteen cents refunded when the tall, narrow building shook in the wind, and management thought it too dangerous to stay inside. The boys were a devilish lot who reveled in throwing things. They brought peas and beans from home, and popcorn from the pool hall, and throughout the show threw as much as they ate. As the bad guys started to get the best of things on the screen, Haslam threw an empty bag which went into the fan over the gallery. It made such a terrible noise that patrons thought the gallery was going to collapse, and headed for the door in terror. Sometimes the flying objects weren’t thrown. It wasn’t unknown to have bats in the first theatre. At such times the women would utter frightened cries and grab their hair. It never kept them away for long though; they always came back for more entertainment. When Babe Muller’s father was manager of the Avenue Lodge in 1920 – 23, Babe would often sing for the audience. She had a lovely voice which the people appreciated, even if the women were shocked at her low-necked dress, and sucked in their voices in surprise when she came on stage. In 1925, Olive Donkersley took over as cashier from Mrs. Meina Tapp and Gladys Thorpe. Ernie Hamerton was the projectionist, Bert Vicars ushered the crowd to their seats, and Glen Hayden played the piano for the movie. Alice Cluff recalls this talented pianist seeing a baby on screen, and playing “You must have been a beautiful baby!” at the infant’s funeral. People didn’t know whether to laugh or cry. He was a tease and should a patron need to leave the building for any reason (there were no inside washrooms), he would suddenly change tunes to draw attention to their actions. Not many ever left. He also supplied the mood music for the fashion shows that took place when salesmen from Vancouver brought their clothes and furs to PR. The local girls modeled the luxurious coats before the movie. One summer John Barrymore and Delores Costello came into the theatre in person. Powell Riverites were a little disillusioned that he seemed much shorter than he looked in the movies, but were thrilled at his presence. When the new Patricia Theatre, an elegant silent movie house, opened in 1928, Vera Evans from Vancouver was hired as organist to entertain during intermission. Myron McLeod was manager and half-owner of McLeod Scanlon Amusement; Joe Buck was his assistant as well as projectionist (and later, manager and projectionist of the Roxy Theatre in Westview and manager of the Patricia); and Bert Vicars was door man. Olive stayed on as cashier until 1940 when she married Jack Gebbie. Her memories of the theatre are many, like the time that it was broken into and robbed. The theatre paid $41 a month to the PR Co. for the services of the night watchman, until the night of the 14th of March 1932, when the safe was blown and the cashbox stolen by notorious criminals, Bagley and Fawcett. The events of that night rivaled the best episode of the “Keystone Cops” on screen. After the safe was repaired, the theatre paid $36 per month for watchman services. The robbery was still talked about when Helen (Young) Meilleur joined the staff in 1937 to work as secretary in the theatre office. Joe buck was still Myron’s assistant; Ian Farquharson had replaced Bert as doorman; Ernie Hamerton operated the projector; Bobby Hatch was janitor and everybody’s assistant; Charlie Rochat delivered the weekly programs, and a long succession of pretty high school girls acted as usherettes. Helen remembers coming when “The japonica and the Japanese cherry and plum trees were in bloom in the theatre ground. I thought this must be the most unique small-town movie house in BC. Perhaps it was. “Since the theatre work was concentrated in the evenings, most of the staff held day-time jobs as well. Myron took on causes; I remember the office at various times being either official or unofficial headquarters for lacrosse, a fish hatchery project, Buy-A-Bomber (wartime fund-raising), Board of Trade, Air Cadets, and School Board Purchasing Committee. There must have been many more. “Tuesday was printing day. The duplicating machine was rolled out to the middle of the main office while Myron and Ernie turned out the week’s programmes. There was lots of ink and paper and noise and a running commentary on the passing scene – and the scene did pass since the office windows looked down on Ocean View Avenue and Second Street, and considerably more. “Saturday matinees were an institution. I’m sure more children shed their frustrations there than parents ever realized. In the safety of the office I listened to hoof beats, heroines’ cries and crashing bridges all interlaced with boos and cheers and yells of young terror. Theatre cash had to be readied for the next show so I was there on Saturdays – and on most holidays for long enough to get it in order. That is why I have some strange memories of snowy, still, Christmas and New Year’s mornings without a single sign of human life in Powell River.” In 1944, parents and loved ones of the boys overseas flocked to see the film that the PR Co. had made of the local service people entitled, Reunion in London. Many tears were shed during the three consecutives showings that were held in the hometown theatre. The show rated higher than Gone With the Wind. ↑ back to top Beryl Goddard spent the summer of ’44 working in the Sweet Shop beside the show during the day, and in the theatre in the evenings. Myron McLeod was then the owner of the Sweet Shop that specialized in real chocolates in big candy jars. Turkish Delights and Banana Splits became part of many Powell Riverites’ evening out to the theatre. Marjorie LaVae joined the staff in 1946 as Mr. McLeod’s private secretary and accountant, serving him well until 1955. Beryl returned to work as usherette that year, and sometime after that a candy counter was put into the lobby of the theatre itself. She was making 50 cents and hour as they filled the theatre night after night. The best-selling show during the thirteen years that Beryl was there was The Ten Commandments, which played for a week. Scottish singers came to entertain on stage three years in a row, and the theatre held a special opera week when they played old operas with stars like Jeannette McDonald. The staff wore white gloves and spiffed themselves up for the performances. The theatre saw several managers during that time including Joe Buck, Mr. Sheveko, Mr. Reid, Al Hammil, Brian Martin, and Harold O’Keefe. Bob Hatch who by this time had worked as a projectionist for some years, was acting-manager when needed. Beryl was related to a number of employees including uncles, Ernie and Jack Hamerton, and aunt Olive Knotts, Ernie’s sister-in-law. Olive Gebbie, her brother Gordy House who was on the door for a time, and daughter Linda. Altogether they counted up sixty years of service to the Patricia. By the time I began working in there in 1959, the wonderful movie-going days were being threatened by television as all Powell River’s living rooms became comfortable theatres. The novelty was overwhelming and competition was never keener. Al Hammil was the manager then, and used many gimmicks to interest people in the movies that were featuring such wonderful stars as Jack Lemmon and Shirley MacLaine. When The Apartment was playing, he advertised it in the “For Rent” column of the classifieds, and when Butterfield 8 was on the marquee, he listed it in the “Personal” section, instructing the reader to phone Butterfield 8. When they did, a recorded message told them about the show, with leading lady, Elizabeth Taylor. As well as Beryl and Linda, the staff included Ken Anderson, the projectionist, Marion Astrope, candy girl, old John Kynock and Jack Hammerton who took tickets at the door, and fellow cashier, Jeannette Meilleur (later Matson), daughter of former employee, Helen Meilleur. Only Jerry Lewis drew a sell-out crowd then. The line twisted and turned up to the corner and around to the United Church. It was alive and writhing with small boys who shook and sprayed their coca cola, and larger fellows who pushed and shoved into a better position. Teen-age girls with back-combed bee-hive hair-dos cajoled and smiled their way into line, making the queue in front of the ticket booth look like a snake that swallowed a frog. The fifteen-cent Saturday matinee was still a madhouse, with wolf-whistles and feet-stamping, and popcorn snowed on seat and aisle. Boys would yell, seats would bang, and the usher would hurry down to cut the commotion, and all would be surprised innocence – in that corner anyway. Evenings were different. Few children came, and adults bought seats at 75 cents each or 90 cents for loges, and enjoyed the quiet show. The “Carry-On Gang” debuted about this time, and ears were strained to hear every line of the English banter. Content was getting more risqué, and the audience roared at Carry on Nurse when they saw a daffodil adorn patient’s just-below-screen derriere. A week before my eighteenth birthday in 1961, black cat banners were pinned across the poster for Room at the Top of the Stairs, the first restricted show to play in the Townsite. Regulations were so stringent at the time that I wasn’t allowed to sell tickets that night even though the cashier’s door could be closed to shut out the sound track. The rule was no one in the theatre under eighteen years of age, and an inspector could be expected to make the rounds of theatres to enforce this rule. There were no inspectors around in the seventies when the entertainment one night featured a soft shoe dancer. Henry Pavid, who was manager then, had met “Miss Linda” at the Rodmay Hotel and invited her to perform her dance routine before the second show. Jokers who recognized her from the Rodmay, began to shout, “Take it off!” “She just let her garment down,” smiled Henry, who had to answer to the RCMP that night, and to Myron McLeod later. The front-page publicity startled everyone, especially those who had not attended a show since the advent of television. It made Babe Muller’s low neckline seem like a coverall. Henry was responsible for much of the better entertainment as well. For years after the last theatre in Vancouver had sold its organ, his velvety strains of music filled the Patricia Theatre before and between shows. It may have been the last theatre in Canada to feature the organ music; the Orpheum in Vancouver still sported an organ but no longer used it. For his last performance Henry tells us he brought in the old silent, Modern Times with Charlie Chaplin, and played “Limelight,” the theme song, and many other selections and improvisations throughout the whole show. Myron McLeod, who had kept the doors of the Patricia Theatre open through the depression and the skim years of the 1950s as well as the cream years of the forties when 31 people were on the payroll, decided to sell. When the decade of the eighties began, it was with new owners, Vi and Bruce McDonald. Today, the Patricia Theatre business that Bobby Scanlon began in 1913 in the narrow building that shook in the wind, is claimed by Mr. McLeod to be the oldest BC theatre business still in operation. See More Remember the exciting silents? The actors rushing about in jerky movements while the train bore down on the maiden tied to the track and the pianist played his best train-bearing-down music. And of course, the villain with his waxed mustache exclaiming,in sub-titles, “Curses, foiled again!” Powell River had its own silent theatre (located at the present cenotaph) where Stan Meade tinkled the ivories, and Bobby Scanlon opened the side door to the children without dimes. He was a well loved manager who controlled the rambunctious teenagers with kindness, and winked at the lovers who sat beneath the balcony. Young Frank Haslam went down after school and flopped back the kitchen chairs to sweep the floor of the old “Pat” theatre. The first four rows of chairs were joined together by a plank underneath, with hinges for easy cleaning. For this service he was allowed to see any show that played, free of charge. He was also part of a pie-eating contest that Bobby held to draw the crowd one night. The spotlight was shone on their blueberry faces as Frank was judged first by Mrs. E.A. Sadler and given the coveted prize, an American silver dollar. Curly Woodward was one of those contestants. It took him a week to get the pie out of his ears. He was a regular customer to the flicks, one who didn’t mind getting his fifteen cents refunded when the tall, narrow building shook in the wind, and management thought it too dangerous to stay inside. The boys were a devilish lot who reveled in throwing things. They brought peas and beans from home, and popcorn from the pool hall, and throughout the show threw as much as they ate. As the bad guys started to get the best of things on the screen, Haslam threw an empty bag which went into the fan over the gallery. It made such a terrible noise that patrons thought the gallery was going to collapse, and headed for the door in terror. Sometimes the flying objects weren’t thrown. It wasn’t unknown to have bats in the first theatre. At such times the women would utter frightened cries and grab their hair. It never kept them away for long though; they always came back for more entertainment. When Babe Muller’s father was manager of the Avenue Lodge in 1920 – 23, Babe would often sing for the audience. She had a lovely voice which the people appreciated, even if the women were shocked at her low-necked dress, and sucked in their voices in surprise when she came on stage. In 1925, Olive Donkersley took over as cashier from Mrs. Meina Tapp and Gladys Thorpe. Ernie Hamerton was the projectionist, Bert Vicars ushered the crowd to their seats, and Glen Hayden played the piano for the movie. Alice Cluff recalls this talented pianist seeing a baby on screen, and playing “You must have been a beautiful baby!” at the infant’s funeral. People didn’t know whether to laugh or cry. He was a tease and should a patron need to leave the building for any reason (there were no inside washrooms), he would suddenly change tunes to draw attention to their actions. Not many ever left. He also supplied the mood music for the fashion shows that took place when salesmen from Vancouver brought their clothes and furs to PR. The local girls modeled the luxurious coats before the movie. One summer John Barrymore and Delores Costello came into the theatre in person. Powell Riverites were a little disillusioned that he seemed much shorter than he looked in the movies, but were thrilled at his presence. When the new Patricia Theatre, an elegant silent movie house, opened in 1928, Vera Evans from Vancouver was hired as organist to entertain during intermission. Myron McLeod was manager and half-owner of McLeod Scanlon Amusement; Joe Buck was his assistant as well as projectionist (and later, manager and projectionist of the Roxy Theatre in Westview and manager of the Patricia); and Bert Vicars was door man. Olive stayed on as cashier until 1940 when she married Jack Gebbie. Her memories of the theatre are many, like the time that it was broken into and robbed. about: Featuring a full-sized stage with in-house PA equipment, in house sound engineers, a 450-capacity room, and a new fully licensed bar. Call now for a quote!
column44: Located in central Cornwall on Montreal Rd., The Port Theatre is as iconic to Cornwall as it’s bridge once was. Originally titled The Roxy, the Port opened in D...ecember of 1941 to glowing success. After it’s opening, the Standard Freeholder called it “one of the finest theatres in the province,” costing approximately $75,000 at the time of it’s construction. Today, the Port still stands strong. Boasting an impressive marquee and distinct lettering, its iconic look has become an area fixture and is a huge part of Cornwall history. Recently purchased by Larry Sylvain (Sylvain Sound), the Port has been bringing in a plethora of live music. Unsurprisingly, it’s layout doubles perfectly as an auditorium that features some amazing acoustics. After all, the room was designed to sound great, making The Port the premier live experience in town. Larry and his team have been working tirelessly to bring live events and world class music back to the forefront of Cornwall, all while delivering a great cinema experience. Featuring a full-sized stage with top-notch PA equipment, in house sound engineers, a 450-capacity room featuring an upper balcony, and a new fully licensed drink bar (19+), The Port Theatre is your next and best choice.  **PLEASE NOTE: WE CURRENTLY DO NOT HAVE AN ONLINE OR TELEPHONE TICKET PURCHASING SYSTEM OR DEBIT. TICKETS FOR ALL EVENTS CAN BE PURCHASED IN PERSON AT THE PORT THEATRE BOX OFFICE OR AT PARTICIPATING CORNWALL LOCATIONS. Welcome to the Powerhouse. Where great food, good friends and a little bit of history come together.
column44: The POWERHOUSE, a historical landmark at the centre of Stoney Creek, provided power for electric rail lines in the 1890s. Now, more than a century later, this s...mall piece of history is home to an exciting restaurant.   Come by and take a seat  at our 18 ft.  bar. Once the vestry at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. We have great space for parties! Experience what The Powerhouse has to offer! column44: There’s been a beer parlour or pub in this location since 1898, and it’s our pleasure to carry on that tradition. At Pub 340, we offer a warm welcome for everyo...ne, whether first-time visitors or folks we see on a regular basis. Whether you come in with a group of friends or alone, you'll always find some friendly faces here.  Visit our website for full details. about: Sir John A. Macdonald
column44: Sir John's Public House is located one half block from Kingston City Hall and Springer Market Square in the historic downtown core. The pub is housed in the his...toric landmark building used by Sir John A. Macdonald as his law office from 1849 to 1860.   The pub features traditional Scottish and contemporary cuisine with a fine selections of appetizers, starters, main courses, desserts and lunch specials. The pub is open daily from 11:00 to close. Try the deep-fried haggis fritters or the Firth of Forth fish & chips. Scottish and local draft beers  are featured as well as Kingston's largest selection of blended and single malt Scotch whiskies.  Visit our web site: www.foodandheritage.com (pending) or call 613-766-92960 for more information about Sir John's Public House. column44: The Rose & Crown was originally a funeral home, built in the 1920's. The histroic building was made into a bar in 1987. When renovating, the owners only changed... what was needed to make it a functional bar. If they could keep aspects that kept it historic, they would. On the third floor you will find the original wallpaper and many artifacts that have been there since the first owners. Walking into to the Rose is very comforting with a warm yellow color and dark wood, it is the perfect place to grab a pint after a hard day of work.  The Rose is rated on of the top four haunted places in Calgary. From its previous use as a funeral home it is no wonder that it is believed ghosts occupy some of the space. It is said that a little boy died in the house who still shows his presence in pictures. Almost everyone who has worked in the building has had some type of encounter or the feeling they're not alone. See More what was needed to make it a functional bar. company overview: Beloved for generations, and dating back to the 1860’s, the historic Senator in the heart of downtown Toronto consists of two distinct rooms - the vintage 1940’...s Diner on our main floor and an intimate Parisian-style Winebar. Both rooms serve the highest quality comfort food with live music in the Winebar on Friday and Saturday nights. See Mores Diner on our main floor and an intimate Parisian-style Winebar. column44: 1860-1929   The house at 249 Victoria Street that was to become the SENATOR, Toronto's oldest restaurant, dates back to the 19th century. The origins of the pro...perty can be traced to the earliest records that were kept by the Town of York, when the area east of Yonge St. was a working class residential neighborhood and Dundas was named Wilton. Representative of the homes built in that era is the historic MACKENZIE HOUSE, circa 1859, on Bond Street, now a popular tourist attraction. At the beginning of the last century, Victoria St. developed into a commercial thoroughfare and the centre for the jewelry trade and in 1926 the property was purchased by the Salvation Army.   1984-2005   In this period, the SENATOR expanded from a family restaurant into one of the most renowned hospitality operations in the city.  The adjacent property earned worldwide acclaim as the Senator Steakhouse and the Top O'The Senator jazz club from 1989-2005.  A sister restaurant to the diner, The Famous, is now in operation in the Fallsview Casino in Niagara Falls, Ontario.  Now in our 76TH year of operation in the same location, we honour everyone - our longtime staff, suppliers and clientele alike - who have contributed to our success. We take constant pride in the traditions and commitment to this family business, which will continue on for generations. The SENATOR began as a home and remains one to our many valued friends and customers. column44: Forget everything you know about BBQ!   We offer a wide selection of BBQ from around the world. With a menu drawing from the best of the best in the BBQ genre, ...such as Texas Brisket, North Carolina Pulled Pork, Tennessee BBQ Chicken, Jamaican Jerk, as well as smoked seafood, and unique and traditional sandwiches. ------------------------------------------------------------  MENU  BITS, BITES, SNACKS & GRAZING - Not quite starters, not quite mains  Wings - Mequite seasoned, double dusted, served by the pound, tossed or sauce on the side (Hot, Pirri Pirri, Sweet Chilli, Memphis Red, BBQ or Jerk)!     Rib Tips - Marinated and fried up crisp, dusted in special seasoning or tossed in a signature sauce (Hot, Pirri Pirri, Sweet Chilli, Memphis Red, BBQ or Jerk)!    Poutine - Spice dusted fries, topped with cheese curds and our BBQ chicken gravy or BBQ sauce.  Add pulled pork for a little extra!    House Salad - Hand torn greens with red onion, cucumber, carrots & peppers topped in our house vinegrette.    Cesear Salad - Hand torn romaine lettuce, cesear dressing, croutons & house smoked bacon.     Steak & Spinach Salad - Grilled rib eye sliced & served with baby spinach, onions, peppers and our house vinegrette.    -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  SANDWICHES - To be eaten with two hands  Pulled Pork - Our pulled pork served on an ACE bakery bun, served solo or topped with our tangy coleslaw.     Pulled Chicken - Our BBQ chicken pulled and simmered in Bourbon BBQ sauce with shredded lettuce.     Shaved Brisket - Our Texas brisket shaved thin and pilled high on an ACE bakery bun served with warm Coffee BBQ sauce for dipping.   The Shaque Burger - 8 oz of house gound beef, seasoned with our house spice blend, charbroiled, glazed with BBQ sauce, and topped with in-house smoked bacon and cheddar cheese.    The DBK - Ask your server for details.  Let's just say it's intense! company overview: Spanning over nine acres, the South Okanagan Events Centre (SOEC) is part of a larger complex. The SOEC Complex contains over 95,000 square feet of meeting spac...e and three ice sheets. While overseeing the Okanagan’s premier sports and entertainment venue, Spectra Venue Management also manages the Penticton Trade and Convention Centre, Memorial Arena, and Okanagan Hockey School Training Centre. While overseeing the Okanagan’s premier sports and entertainment venue, Spectra Venue Management also manages the Penticton Trade and Convention Centre, Memorial Arena, and Okanagan Hockey School Training Centre.
column44: Spanning over nine acres, the South Okanagan Events Centre (SOEC) is part of a larger complex. The SOEC Complex contains over 95,000 square feet of meeting spac...e and three ice sheets. While overseeing the Okanagan’s premier sports and entertainment venue, Spectra Venue Management also manages the Penticton Trade and Convention Centre, Memorial Arena, and Okanagan Hockey School Training Centre. The SOEC is also home of the Penticton Vees Junior 'A' Hockey Club.  All official ticketing for the complex can be purchased through the Valley First Box Office (located at Gate One of the SOEC), via phone at 1.877.763.2849 or online at ValleyFirstTIX.com.   For major events and concerts, the public parking lots at the South Okanagan Events Centre (SOEC) are “Pay and Display” parking. The cash only fee is $10.00. Address: 2066 Kingsway ( Kingsway @ Victoria ) Vancouver, British Columbia
about: Not Fancy - Just Fresh
public transit: The #20 #19 and #25 can all get you almost to the front door
column44: The Tipper Restaurant nestled in Kingsway and Victoria intersection is the kind of place where owner Colin Shandler demonstrates that people and the product com...e before profit. It is also the kind of place that customers have coined as one of the city’s hidden gems. “Simple, unassuming, and humbly fresh” says Shandler, describing both the atmosphere and the menu creations. Something he accredits to the hand-picked produce and meats from within the community. ‘Community’ is definitely the emphasis here. Local art hangs on the wall, musicians perform in the Review Room, and the window seats are usually filled with writers, students, and families. The Review Room in the back not only provides a venue for performers but also plays host to community events on any given day of the week. When the Revue Room, a private performance and meeting space set in the back half of the restaurant isn’t housing local music collectives The Tipper hosts AA meetings Thursday and Sunday of every week, and a parents and tot play group on Fridays. Whether enjoying free run eggs and bacon for breakfast (served every day until 5pm), or a free run “Cliff and Ed” cajun chicken burger with home cut yam fries for dinner, the menu also includes several vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free options, and home-made hollandaise sauce for weekend bennies, and other home-made sauces and soups all week. However, The Tipper experience does not end with what comes out of the kitchen, the bar too consists of unique spirits and local draught, and Vancouver’s own JJ Bean coffee. The service staff is mature and laid back, as is the general style of service that Shandler aims for. The fun and fresh staff are always attentive and aware but never overbearing or pushy, and they’ll always share a laugh or a story. The community vibe is apparent in the way the staff interacts both with guests and each other. For the Kensington Cedar Cottage neighborhood, the Tipper is the spot!  The Tipper as Brenna sees it See Moree before profit. column44: At The Toucan, we love our sports, especially soccer. We show live games in the following leagues; EPL, Champions League, NFL, NHL, MLB and All World Championsh...ips.   The Toucan has been a main stay in the live music scene in Kingston since the early nineties, hosting many Canadian legends over the years. Today, we have live music every Monday, Tuesday, Friday, Saturday and DJ’s on Sundays:   - Live Band Mondays 10:30pm to 2am we feature different local bands on a monthly rotation.   - Irish Seisiún Tuesdays 8pm-11pm we host an informal gathering at which people play traditional Irish music – anyone can join or watch!  - Acoustic Fridays 5pm-8pm we have live acoustic music featuring a local artist upstairs in Kirkpatrick’s.   - Live Music Fridays & Saturdays 10:30pm-2am featuring local, up & coming, & independent bands from afar.   - Hip Hop Sundays 11pm-2am featuring DJ Swordwall & a visual projection show. about: The Wolf Performance Hall is a beautiful and intimate theatre designed for both memorable performances and exceptional meetings.
column44: A stage isn’t just a stage. It’s where ideas come to life.  Whether you’re a making your musical or theatrical debut, sharing your story or presenting an idea t...o inspire, one thing’s for sure, the secret to a great performance or presentation is connecting with your audience.  Wolf Performance Hall’s tiered seating, excellent sightlines and outstanding acoustics makes it one of London’s most sought after intimate venues for performers and audience members alike. company overview: Third Space Café is a coffee shop and social enterprise that seeks to provide ethically-sourced, high quality food and beverages, while also contributing to the... alleviation of poverty and providing meaningful work experience in the local community.   Third Space Café is the first specialty coffee shop in Niagara Falls to specifically focus on social impact in addition to sales. Our target neighbourhoods display serious needs around mental health, addictions, food and housing security, lack of meaningful employment, and discrimination. Our goals are to bring awareness to these issues through social initiatives, events, and fundraising with a local impact; while at the same time providing a high-quality specialty coffee experience that is based on fair-trade practices, equality, and dignity for all. column44: LEGENDARY CAMDEN MUSIC VENUE  Camden’s famous Lock 17 at Camden Lock was relaunched on 22nd June 2016, following a two-month, £300,000 renovation. ...  The project will see the venue build on its historic roots as a legendary live music venue for big name and emerging talent.   The venue will also continue to host London’s hottest new comedy club, The Comedy Loft, in addition to its famous club nights and impressive rooftop bar overlooking Camden Lock.   BY DAY   Feeling hungry? Come down for a bite to eat and choose from a selection of burgers and mains including pub favourites like fish & chips or steak, or something more international like our chimichurri chicken or panang curry!   Fancy a drink? Choose from a range of beers and cocktails, a wealth of spirits, and a selection of wines and fizz! Happy Hour runs from 5pm-7pm Monday to Friday and gives you 50% off selected drinks... Nice!   BY NIGHT  With weekly comedy shows in the Comedy Loft, an array of live music performances in Dingwalls, and the sickest clubnights and events filling the entire building every week, theres certain to be something for everyone! Act Name: The Happiness of Pursuit Music Festival
about: The Happiness of Pursuit Festival is an annual Music & Lifestyle Festival based in Ontario, California with alumni including Conway, Benny The Butcher, Mobb Deep, Obie Trice, Murs, Fashawn, Grieves, Skyzoo, Elzhi, R.A. The Rugged Man, 60 East and more.
company overview: The Happiness of Pursuit Music Festival is an annual, single-day, hip hop music and culture festival that takes place in Ontario, California. The Festival was f...ounded by Hometown Hero and International Hip Hop Artist Joey "60 East" Atilano, who grew up in the city and after having much success as an Artist around the world, decided to come back home and create something that can draw others to his home. THOPFest draws in 1,000+ patrons from southern California, Arizona, and beyond. THoP Fest is dedicated to the progression and preservation of hip hop music and culture, viewing the youth and the elders as equal and essential in doing so. With a wide range of sub-genres within hip hop represented, attendees will range in age from 21-50 with the bulk of those in attendance between the ages of 21 and 32. Desiring to progress the genre, we will be creating a space that is safe, comfortable, and attractive to everyone. While the music is as the core of our mission and vision, we desire to provide patrons with an experience that they will carry with them forever, and that will leave them looking forward to the next Happiness of Pursuit Music Festival. Page Types: Performance Art Theatre | Nonprofit Organization | Theatrical Play
about: Canada's Dockside Theatre. Presenting professional live theatre in the heart of the 1000 Islands for over 35 years.
products: Tickets, Subscriptions, Memberships
column44: In 1981, Greg Wanless returned home from a number of successful seasons at Stratford with the dream of reestablishing a theatre in Gananoque.  For a short time,... from 1967-1968, Gananoque had been home to the St. Lawrence Summer Playhouse, located in a tent in the parking lot of the Blinkbonnie Hotel. The theatre was extremely popular with locals and tourists alike, featuring a mix of Broadway musicals and American and British comedies.  But despite its success, it was soon moved to Kingston where it continued running until 1976.  Greg’s desire to bring theatre back to Gananoque was met with considerable support from the community, which had deeply missed the activity and excitement generated by the previous Playhouse. Under Greg’s leadership, and with the help of the community and a close group of artists and actors, the Thousand Islands Playhouse presented its first show on June 25, 1982.  The local Rotary Club sold the Gananoque Canoe Club to the Playhouse, community members donated money to renovate the building, and tradespeople generously gave of their time and expertise. That first season it was not unusual to come across a local businessman working alongside an actor building a deck, or a plumber teaching people how to install a toilet. Community members often dropped by after work to check on the progress of the building, and hosted dinners for hungry performers or production staff.  After such passionate community involvement in the theatre’s beginnings, it seemed natural that the Playhouse’s mission statement include an acknowledgment of our commitment to community life. Thirty years later, the Playhouse remains an important part of life in Gananoque and our commitment to the community continues to guide our artistic vision. about: Wind through Pacific Rim Park to downtown Tofino’s revitalized landmark and gateway to the water: Tofino Resort + Marina, 63 rooms overlooking the inlet.
column44: Inspired by Adventure Introducing Tofino's newest oceanfront resort.  ... Wind through Pacific Rim Park to downtown Tofino's revitalized landmark and gateway to the water. Tofino Resort + Marina, 63 rooms overlooking the Clayoquot Sound UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.  Come check out our flagship restaurant, 1909 Kitchen.   Honouring the history of our coastal locale, our restaurant was named after the year Tofino got its name. With a fresh take on local ingredients, our shared plates are devised by up-and-coming chef with an impressive pedigree, Paul Moran. Unwind off the water with wood-fired bites or a libation inspired by the tides.   The Hatch Waterfront Pub  Grab a friend and a cold one, and pull up a barstool. This is the Hatch: our local pub where wayfarers and locals alike take in the views and live music. It's the place to cheers the day, tell stories into the night, and leave with friends new and old.  Open from 11am to 12am daily. See More Wind through Pacific Rim Park to downtown Tofino's revitalized landmark and gateway to the water. about: Producing concerts and tours for television productions, corporate entities, large scale festivals, government offices, private individuals, and the general public in Western Canada. Books for MacEwan Hall, Ballroom, The Den and Theatre Junction.
public transit: Producing concerts and tours for television productions, corporate entities, large scale festivals, government offices, private individuals, and the general pub...lic, Calgary based “Tooth Blackner Presents” has garnered a strong reputation in Western Canada.  Exclusively booking the University of Calgary venues, including the MacEwan Ballroom, The Den, and MacEwan Hall, along with the Grand Theatre in downtown Calgary, Tooth Blackner Presents produces over 100 shows per year, from folk to punk to children’s performances to jazz and everything in between.   While it was officially formed in 2005, Tooth Blackner Presents has been the work of sole-owner Greg Curtis, for over twenty years. Greg began as an employee, and then a contracted employee, of the University of Calgary Students’ Union and his business progressed from there. The formation of Tooth Blackner Presents has allowed for expansion of Greg’s working relationships, influence, and involvement in the music industry in Western Canada. Having spent years in the broadcast media and studying Theatre at the Univeristy of Calgary (BFA 1988), as well as working with numerous not-for-profit organizations including sitting on the board of The Calgary Folk Festival (Vice-chair), The Canadian Organization of Campus Activities, The Western Canadian Music Alliance, The Calgary Juno Host Committee Executive, and Music Calgary Executive, Greg is considered an asset to the live music scene in Calgary and Canada. about: Ontario's largest theatre & performance festival.
general information: Our primary activities include:   -	The Fringe Festival: Presenting 150 productions chosen by lottery at venues across the city, the Fringe attracts 90,000+ att...endees and returns $400,000+ to participating artists -	The Next Stage Theatre Festival: Presenting 8-10 productions from the best Fringe companies across the world, NSTF is a showcase for emerging talent ready to be seen by new audiences and programmers -	Youth and Artist Outreach Activities: Our outreach programs offer in-depth support to young audiences and emerging artists, promoting participation in theatre and providing resources to professionalize independent artistic undertakings See Moreendees and returns $400,000+ to participating artists -	The Next Stage Theatre Festival: Presenting 8-10 productions from the best Fringe companies across the world, NSTF is a showcase for emerging talent ready to be seen by new audiences and programmers -	Youth and Artist Outreach Activities: Our outreach programs offer in-depth support to young audiences and emerging artists, promoting participation in theatre and providing resources to professionalize independent artistic undertakings
mission: We are dedicated to enabling access to creative opportunities for artists and audiences, and to encourage the enterprise of independent artists by providing the, space, time, and resources for their work to take shape.
company overview: The Toronto Fringe produces two annual festivals - The Toronto Fringe Festival & The Next Stage Festival.
column44: For 31 years, The Toronto Fringe has acted as an incubator for ideas, reputations and experiences, dedicated to helping artists succeed. Through the incredibly ...popular Fringe Festival, we’ve created a dynamic and diverse community that has proven the power of the independent spirit by becoming the largest theatre festival in the city and the launching pad for some of Canada’s most recognized cultural exports. about: Toronto Island Marina
column44: Webster's Collegiate Dictionary defines Marina as: "a dock or basin providing secure moorings for motorboats or yachts". We believe this to be a fair descriptio...n of your average marina. Sure, we have secure moorings for your boat, the Toronto Island Marina has over 350 berths to accommodate you. However, we like to think of our marina as much more than a place to tie up your craft.   While most marinas may offer similar services to the Toronto Island Marina, we are certain that none offer the quality of our environment! Nestled between picturesque Centre and Muggs Islands in Toronto's inner harbour, it's intimate and calm; not just another liquid parking lot. The air is fresh and everywhere you look there is green. To the north, within an easy ferry ride, you'll see Toronto, one of the world's great cities.  As you step off your boat at the Toronto Island Marina, you step into 500 acres of lush park land. Enjoy island life - a peaceful setting for seafarers of all ages, with all the expansive greenery of the Toronto Islands at your disposal. Walk, or picnic, or play. Bring the children, bring the dog. Life's short. Have fun. For a change of pace, step onto our private tender, or stroll to the island ferry.  When you have had enough of the hustle, the noise and the concrete, remember you're just a wave away from an island of green peace and tranquility - the Toronto Island Marina.  So whether you're mooring your boat for the season or visiting for the weekend, come and get away - and be welcome to our world. See Moren of your average marina. mission: Toronto Summer Music’s festival and academy enrich lives through the shared appreciation  of music.  We have a two-fold, interconnected mission:  We present con...certs with world- renowned artists for a diverse audience; and we operate an Academy that offers high-level  training and performance opportunities for emerging musicians.  Throughout both of these strands of activity we actively promote engagement between our musicians and their audiences. See Morecerts with world- renowned artists for a diverse audience; and we operate an Academy that offers high-level  training and performance opportunities for emerging musicians.  Throughout both of these strands of activity we actively promote engagement between our musicians and their audiences.
company overview: An international classical music festival and academy now entering its 12th season, Toronto Summer Music (TSM) brings world-renowned performing artists to Toron...to for an unparalleled combination of performances and summer music education.    Programmed by our recently appointed, celebrated Artistic Director, Jonathan Crow, the TSM Festival offers classical music lovers a feast of engaging concerts, enriched by master classes, lectures, exhibitions and workshops.  The only summer music program of its kind in Ontario, the TSM Academy offers instruction at the highest level to musicians at the threshold of their professional careers through individual master classes and string quartet, composition and chamber music workshops. The Joseph Richard Group is a BC company that specializes in providing our guests with... a familiar place to call home.  Featuring craft cocktails, craft beer, a spectacular wine list, classic pub fare,  and deliciously addictive modern menu options. See More a familiar place to call home.  Featuring craft cocktails, craft beer, a spectacular wine list, classic pub fare,  and deliciously addictive modern menu options.
column44: At Townhall, we pair a comfortable atmosphere and exceptional service with really, really good grub. Let us be your stomping ground, your escape route, your saf...e haven, your happy place. Stop by to watch the game or join us for a drink (fyi, we’ve got more than a dozen beers on tap and 25 craft brews to choose from). We have a hunch that you’ll be enticed to stay and sample one of our classic pub offerings, all prepared from fresh, high-quality ingredients. More than just a pub, we care about the people in our community. That’s why we fundraise for schools and charities, strive to support local neighbourhood food producers and keep our communities out of harm’s way by participating in local safety initiatives. Let us be your stomping ground, your escape route, your safe haven, your happy place. And in return, we’ll offer you a night you’ll remember long after the sun comes up. With our cozy ambiance, top quality fare and cheerful grins, we know you’ll be able to kick back and unwind, as if you were lounging in your own living room. Just keep your pants on, ok? Page Types: Landmark & Historical Place | Public & Government Service
Address: 285 St. George Street, Box 310 Annapolis Royal, Nova Scotia
about: Annapolis Royal is a pleasure to behold for the visitor, a dynamic community with growing opportunity for business investment, and a home second to none for its residents.
general information: The Annapolis Royal area has gained a reputation as a vibrant centre for cultural activity, and over the years it has become a magnet for visual artists, crafts...people, performers and writers. No fewer than eight private studios and galleries are in operation within the National Historic District, not to mention an artist-run gallery (ARTsPLACE) and another art gallery at King's Theatre.  We're proud of our many well-preserved heritage buildings that make up one of the loveliest streetscapes in the country. We're also pleased to be recognized as a community where volunteerism is alive and well. Visitors are often surprised that so many activities go on in such a sparsely populated area. See Morepeople, performers and writers. column44: A beautiful community nestled in the Annapolis Valley, and originally inhabited by a strong Mi'kmaq community, the area became home in 1605 to some of North Ame...rica's earliest European settlers. With an amazing history and an exciting present day, Annapolis Royal is a pleasure to behold for the visitor, a dynamic community with growing opportunity for business investment, and a home second to none for its residents. founding date: 1999 (Amalgamated - Essex, Colchester North, Colchester South, & Harrow)
mission: The Town’s mission is to maintain existing services, and to develop new ones, assets and opportunities that will deliver an outstanding life experience for present and future residents, communities, businesses, and visitors.
column44: The Town of Essex is located in southwestern Ontario, approximately 28 kilometres southeast of the City of Windsor and is one of seven lower-tier municipalities... in the County of Essex. The Town of Essex consists of four distinct and unique centres – Essex Centre, Harrow Centre, McGregor Centre and Colchester Centre. These unique communities are surrounded by a thriving wine and agriculture industry and boast a wide range of recreational facilities, an excellent school system, and affordable living options. The current population of the Town of Essex is 19,600. See More in the County of Essex. company overview: The Town of Fox Creek runs a number of different departments - the general and contact information can be found below.   Administration Office - come visit us h...ere for information on your taxes, to pay that pesky water bill or just get informed on the general information of what is going on in the community.   Open Monday - Thursday 8:00 am - 4:30 pm  and Friday 8:00 am - 1:00 pm  Community Resource Centre - The true heart of the community. Offering programs for babies all the way up to seniors, the community resource centre has something for everyone. You will also find employment services, Parent Link Centre, Adult Education, Literacy Services and much more here!   Open Monday - Thursday 8:00 am - 4:30 pm and Friday 8:00 am - 1:00 pm.   Public Works - looks after all of the maintenance of the town. Makes sure the potholes are filled, the toilets flush and the streets are cleaned.   Contact the Administration Office to get a hold of Public Works.   Recreation - The new Fox Creek Greenview Multiplex is open!  Recreation also offers recreation programs to the community as well as running our three campgrounds and making sure we have beautiful flowers and our grass is cut.   Contact the Administration Office to get a hold of Public Works   Fox Creek Medical Clinic - Operating out of the Fox Creek hospital.
